CHAPTER I.
I GO TO STYLES

annotation:
Speaker: Captain Arthur Hastings (the story's first-person narrator and friend/biographer of Hercule Poirot).
Addressed to: the general reader/public (those who followed the press coverage and who will read this book).
Topic: Hastings explains that, at the request of his friend Poirot and the Styles family, he is writing a full account of "The Styles Case" (the notorious murder and investigation) to dispel sensational rumours.
Where/when: Hastings is writing after the events and publicity have died down (in England, after the trial/investigation), presenting a retrospective account.
fragment:
The intense interest aroused in the public by what was known at the
time as “The Styles Case” has now somewhat subsided. Nevertheless, in
view of the world-wide notoriety which attended it, I have been asked,
both by my friend Poirot and the family themselves, to write an account
of the whole story. This, we trust, will effectually silence the
sensational rumours which still persist.

annotation:
- Speaker: Captain Arthur Hastings, the first‑person narrator and friend of Hercule Poirot.
- Addressee: the general reader/public (he is writing an account at the request of Poirot and the Styles family).
- Topic: He will briefly describe how he came to be connected with the well‑known "Styles Case" — i.e., the circumstances that led to his involvement.
- Setting/context: Opening of his written narrative ("I Go to Styles"); he is preparing to recount the events at Styles Court that follow.
fragment:
I will therefore briefly set down the circumstances which led to my
being connected with the affair.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first‑person narrator — Captain Arthur Hastings, a former British Army officer and a friend/associate of Hercule Poirot, who has been asked by Poirot and the family to write up the events.
- Who is addressed: This is a narrative addressed to the reader (an account of past events), not a line of dialogue to another character.
- Topic: Hastings explains that he was invalided home from the Front, spent time in a convalescent home, was on sick leave, and then unexpectedly ran into John Cavendish; this chance meeting (and Hastings’ childhood connection with the Cavendish family) sets up his involvement with the household at Styles.
- Where: Hastings has been recuperating in a convalescent home in England and is on sick leave; Styles is the Cavendish family’s country house in Essex, where Hastings had stayed as a boy.
fragment:
I had been invalided home from the Front; and, after spending some
months in a rather depressing Convalescent Home, was given a month’s
sick leave. Having no near relations or friends, I was trying to make
up my mind what to do, when I ran across John Cavendish. I had seen
very little of him for some years. Indeed, I had never known him
particularly well. He was a good fifteen years my senior, for one
thing, though he hardly looked his forty-five years. As a boy, though,
I had often stayed at Styles, his mother’s place in Essex.

annotation:
- Speaker: Dr. John H. Watson, the first‑person narrator (a retired/invalided army doctor).
- Addressed to: the reader / general public (Watson is recounting events for publication).
- Topic: Watson and his old acquaintance John Cavendish chatted about past times; Cavendish invited Watson to spend his sick leave at Styles.
- Where: the conversation was with John Cavendish (met after Watson was invalided home); "Styles" is Cavendish's mother’s country house in Essex, where Watson is being invited to go.
fragment:
We had a good yarn about old times, and it ended in his inviting me
down to Styles to spend my leave there.

annotation:
Speaker: John Cavendish ("he").
Addressee: the first‑person narrator (the wounded soldier who had been on sick leave).
Topic: John is reassuring the narrator that his mother ("the mater") will be pleased to see the narrator again after many years — part of an invitation to spend his sick‑leave at Styles, the Cavendish family home.
Where: during the conversation when John Cavendish ran into the narrator and invited him to Styles (the Cavendish house in Essex).
fragment:
“The mater will be delighted to see you again—after all those years,”
he added.

annotation:
Speaker: the first‑person narrator (the soldier recently invalided home on sick leave).
Addressee: John Cavendish, whom the narrator has just met again.
Topic: a polite inquiry about the health of John’s mother (“the mater”) — following John’s remark that she would be delighted to see the narrator.
Where: during their conversation after they ran across one another (i.e., the street or similar public place where they reconnected, just before arrangements to visit Styles are made).
fragment: “Your mother keeps well?” I asked.

annotation:
Speaker: the man who had just invited the narrator down to Styles (the friend referred to as “he” in the preceding lines).
Addressee: the narrator (first-person speaker who asked “Your mother keeps well?” — in the original story this is Dr. Watson).
Topic: answering the question about his mother — he says she is well and adds that she has remarried.
Where: in the same private conversation where the invitation to Styles was made (i.e., in the friend’s company, before going down to the Styles estate — likely in town or the friend’s rooms). The word “mater” in the earlier line means “mother.”
fragment: “Oh, yes. I suppose you know that she has married again?”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The passage is the narrator ("I") speaking/reflecting. Earlier lines show a male interlocutor (referred to as "he") and the narrator exchanging remarks; the narrator had just asked about the other's mother.
- Who is addressed: The narrator is speaking to/about John (the other person in the scene) and commenting on John’s mother, Mrs. Cavendish.
- What is the topic: A description of Mrs. Cavendish — that she married John’s father (becoming stepmother when he was a widower with two sons), her present advanced age (about seventy), her former appearance and energetic, autocratic, charitable personality (opening bazaars, playing "Lady Bountiful"), and that she is generous and wealthy.
- Where they are / context: The remarks occur during a social conversation about visiting or seeing family after many years (a reunion/visit involving the Cavendish family); the narrator is recalling Mrs. Cavendish from memory in that context.
fragment:
I am afraid I showed my surprise rather plainly. Mrs. Cavendish, who
had married John’s father when he was a widower with two sons, had been
a handsome woman of middle-age as I remembered her. She certainly could
not be a day less than seventy now. I recalled her as an energetic,
autocratic personality, somewhat inclined to charitable and social
notoriety, with a fondness for opening bazaars and playing the Lady
Bountiful. She was a most generous woman, and possessed a considerable
fortune of her own.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The story's first-person narrator (the "I" who asked "Your mother keeps well?"; likely Hastings in the original).
- Who is addressed: In the preceding dialogue the narrator was speaking to John Cavendish; this paragraph is narrator's recollection told to the reader.
- Topic: Background history of the Cavendish family — their country house (Styles Court), Mrs. Cavendish's dominance in life and in her husband's will (she held the estate for life and most of the income), the potential unfairness to her two stepsons, and her generous, maternal treatment of them.
- Where: This is narrative exposition/flashback about the family seat (Styles Court) and past arrangements, not a scene taking place at that location in the present moment of the conversation.
fragment:
Their country-place, Styles Court, had been purchased by Mr. Cavendish
early in their married life. He had been completely under his wife’s
ascendancy, so much so that, on dying, he left the place to her for her
lifetime, as well as the larger part of his income; an arrangement that
was distinctly unfair to his two sons. Their step-mother, however, had
always been most generous to them; indeed, they were so young at the
time of their father’s remarriage that they always thought of her as
their own mother.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first‑person narrator (the same speaker as in the preceding lines — the narrator of the story, recounting family history).
- Who is addressed: Not directly addressed to anyone in the fragment; it is part of the narrator’s account to his conversational companion/reader.
- Topic: A brief biographical sketch of Lawrence Cavendish — the younger of the two Cavendish sons. He was delicate, trained as a doctor but gave up medical practice, remained living at home, and tried to be a poet (with no real success).
- Where they are / context: This is background information about the Cavendish family and their life at Styles Court, offered amid a conversation about Mrs. Cavendish’s remarriage.
fragment:
Lawrence, the younger, had been a delicate youth. He had qualified as a
doctor but early relinquished the profession of medicine, and lived at
home while pursuing literary ambitions; though his verses never had any
marked success.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first‑person narrator — an observer describing the Cavendish family (in the original story this is the narrator of the tale).
- Who is addressed: The reader (general narration / telling of past events).
- What is the topic: John Cavendish’s career and domestic situation — he trained as a barrister, became a country squire, married recently and moved his wife into Styles Court, but remains financially dependent on his stepmother. The passage emphasizes Mrs. Cavendish’s control of the family finances (the “purse strings”) and the narrator’s belief that John would have preferred a larger allowance so he could live independently.
- Where they are / context: The account concerns Styles Court, the Cavendish family’s country house; the narrator is relating memories and observations about the household and family arrangements.
fragment:
John practised for some time as a barrister, but had finally settled
down to the more congenial life of a country squire. He had married two
years ago, and had taken his wife to live at Styles, though I
entertained a shrewd suspicion that he would have preferred his mother
to increase his allowance, which would have enabled him to have a home
of his own. Mrs. Cavendish, however, was a lady who liked to make her
own plans, and expected other people to fall in with them, and in this
case she certainly had the whip hand, namely: the purse strings.

annotation:
Speaker: the first-person narrator (Captain Arthur Hastings).  
Addressee/other person: John Cavendish — the elder son of the Cavendish family, who lives at Styles Court.  
Topic: the narrator’s surprise on hearing the news that John’s step‑mother (Mrs. Cavendish) has remarried; John notices this and responds with a rueful smile.  
Setting: at Styles Court, the family’s country house (the Cavendishes’ home).
fragment:
John noticed my surprise at the news of his mother’s remarriage and
smiled rather ruefully.

annotation:
- Speaker: John Cavendish (the "John" mentioned in the prior lines).
- Addressed to: Hastings (the narrator, Captain Arthur Hastings).
- Topic: John is angrily referring to Mrs. Cavendish’s new husband ("rotten little bounder") and complaining that the mother’s remarriage is making life difficult for the family; he then brings up "Evie" (someone Hastings is expected to remember — likely a younger female family member or acquaintance).
- Where: At Styles (the Cavendish home), during the conversation between John and Hastings about Mrs. Cavendish’s remarriage.
fragment:
“Rotten little bounder too!” he said savagely. “I can tell you,
Hastings, it’s making life jolly difficult for us. As for Evie—you
remember Evie?”

annotation:
Speaker: Hastings (the narrator).
Addressed to: John Cavendish.
Topic: John's question "You remember Evie?" — Hastings' one-word reply "No." indicates he does not remember/know Evie. The exchange follows John talking about his mother's remarriage and family difficulties.
Where: At Styles (John's country house), during the two men's conversation.
fragment: “No.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: John (the man who earlier mentioned his mother's remarriage).
- Who is addressed: "I" — the narrator, called Hastings in the history (the person John was speaking to).
- Topic: John is describing "Evie," the mother's long-serving companion/factotum. He says Evie worked for the family before Hastings knew her ("after your time"), characterizes her as a versatile servant ("factotum," "Jack of all trades"), not young or conventionally beautiful but lively, good-humored ("a great sport") and plucky ("as game as they make them").
- Where they are / context: Immediately after John told Hastings about his mother’s remarriage; they are together discussing the household and the people involved (most likely in or near John's home).  
- Notes on language: "Mater" = mother; "factotum"/"Jack of all trades" = general household helper who does many tasks; "after your time" = employed there before Hastings knew the place; "a great sport"/"game" = fun, good-natured, willing.
fragment:
“Oh, I suppose she was after your time. She’s the mater’s factotum,
companion, Jack of all trades! A great sport—old Evie! Not precisely
young and beautiful, but as game as they make them.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hastings (the man who earlier replied “No.”).
- Who is addressed: the male speaker who had been talking “savagely” about the “rotten little bounder” and describing Evie.
- Topic: prompting the other man to finish an unfinished remark — i.e., to continue what he was going to say about Evie / the troublemaker who is “making life jolly difficult.”
- Where they are: in the same room having the conversation (likely in or near the speaker’s family/home setting — the house connected with “the mater”).
fragment: “You were going to say——?”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The same person who was just praising "Evie" in the previous line (call them Speaker A) — a member of the household or an acquaintance who gossips about household affairs.
- Who is addressed: The other interlocutor in the conversation (Speaker B), who had interrupted with "You were going to say——?"
- What is the topic: Gossip about a newly arrived man who claims to be a relative of Evie (the mater's factotum/companion). The speaker calls him an "outsider," describes his appearance (big black beard, patent-leather boots), and says "the mater" immediately hired him as a secretary despite the speaker's misgivings; the tone is suspicious and dismissive.
- Where they are: Not explicitly stated in the fragment, but the context (talk of "the mater," Evie as factotum, and domestic societies) indicates a private, domestic setting — likely a drawing room or sitting-room in the household where the mother ("the mater") runs social societies.
fragment:
“Oh, this fellow! He turned up from nowhere, on the pretext of being a
second cousin or something of Evie’s, though she didn’t seem
particularly keen to acknowledge the relationship. The fellow is an
absolute outsider, anyone can see that. He’s got a great black beard,
and wears patent leather boots in all weathers! But the mater cottoned
to him at once, took him on as secretary—you know how she’s always
running a hundred societies?”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The line "I nodded." is the narrator (first-person "I") performing a nonverbal response.
- Who is addressed: The nod is directed to the previous speaker — a companion/friend who has been describing "Evie" and a mysterious man.
- What is the topic: The conversation is about Evie (the mother's factotum/companion) and an outsider — a bearded man who has turned up and been taken on as the narrator's mother's secretary.
- Where they are: A domestic setting (the family home, likely a sitting-room or drawing-room) where the narrator and the friend are talking.
fragment: I nodded.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The same woman who was gossiping in the previous lines (an acquaintance/family friend), continuing her account.
- Who is addressed: The narrator ("I"), who has just nodded; the speaker is talking directly to them.
- Topic: Gossip about "the fellow" (named Alfred) — he turned up as a supposed cousin of Evie, was taken on as the mother's ("mater") secretary, and has now become engaged to and married the mother. The speaker suspects he is much younger (about twenty years younger) and a fortune-hunter; she also attributes part of the change to effects of the war ("the war has turned the hundreds into thousands").
- Where they are: In an interior domestic setting (a private sitting-room or similar), engaged in a personal conversation — the same scene as the earlier exchange.
fragment:
“Well, of course the war has turned the hundreds into thousands. No
doubt the fellow was very useful to her. But you could have knocked us
all down with a feather when, three months ago, she suddenly announced
that she and Alfred were engaged! The fellow must be at least twenty
years younger than she is! It’s simply bare-faced fortune hunting; but
there you are—she is her own mistress, and she’s married him.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator ("I") — the person who had been listening and nodding.
- Who is addressed: The friend/acquaintance who was gossiping about her family (the one who complained about "this fellow" and "the mater").
- Topic: A sympathetic response to the friend's story about her mother ("the mater") suddenly marrying a much younger man (Alfred), an outsider suspected of fortune-hunting; the narrator is acknowledging that the situation must be difficult for the friend's family.
- Where: In the same face-to-face conversation (a domestic social setting — a parlour/drawing-room or similar), during a visit or informal chat.
fragment: “It must be a difficult situation for you all.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The same person who gave the long complaint in the previous line — an angry family member or household acquaintance who has just been describing the engagement.  
- Who is addressed: The narrator ("I") and others present in the conversation.  
- What is the topic: Outrage about "her" sudden engagement to Alfred, a man at least twenty years younger (called fortune-hunting); anger at how the war has affected money and at the marriage.  
- Where they are: In the private room where the conversation is taking place (a domestic sitting room/drawing-room).
fragment: “Difficult! It’s damnable!”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator, "I" — Captain Arthur Hastings.
- Who is addressed: The reader / general audience (Hastings is narrating past events); the immediate action involves John Cavendish meeting him.
- What is the topic: Hastings describes arriving at Styles St. Mary three days after the preceding conversation (in which members of the household complained about an older wealthy woman—Mrs. Inglethorp—having married a much younger man, Alfred, suspected of fortune-hunting). He is being received by John Cavendish, who pilots him to the car to go on to the Styles estate.
- Where they are: At the tiny country railway station of Styles St. Mary, in the countryside en route to the Styles household/estate.
fragment:
Thus it came about that, three days later, I descended from the train
at Styles St. Mary, an absurd little station, with no apparent reason
for existence, perched up in the midst of green fields and country
lanes. John Cavendish was waiting on the platform, and piloted me out
to the car.

annotation:
- Speaker: John Cavendish (the man who met the narrator on the platform).
- Addressed to: the narrator ("I"), as they stand by the car preparing to drive.
- Topic: a remark that there is still a little petrol/fuel in the car ("a drop or two of petrol"), which he attributes to his mother's (referred to colloquially as "the mater") actions—i.e., she has seen to keeping/bringing fuel.
- Where: at Styles St. Mary railway station, on the platform beside the automobile.
fragment:
“Got a drop or two of petrol still, you see,” he remarked. “Mainly
owing to the mater’s activities.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: John Cavendish (the young man who met the narrator at the station).
- Who is addressed: the narrator, the "I" who arrived by train and is riding with John.
- What is the topic: their arrival at Styles Court and the contrast between the peaceful Essex countryside and the ongoing Great War; they are turning into the lodge gates of the country house.
- Where they are: in Essex, approaching Styles Court (the manor) after leaving Styles St. Mary station on a warm July afternoon; they are in the car, turning in at the lodge gates. "Mater" in the earlier line refers to John's mother.
fragment:
The village of Styles St. Mary was situated about two miles from the
little station, and Styles Court lay a mile the other side of it. It
was a still, warm day in early July. As one looked out over the flat
Essex country, lying so green and peaceful under the afternoon sun, it
seemed almost impossible to believe that, not so very far away, a great
war was running its appointed course. I felt I had suddenly strayed
into another world. As we turned in at the lodge gates, John said:

annotation:
- Speaker: John Cavendish (the man who met the narrator at the station).
- Addressed to: "Hastings" — the narrator, Captain Arthur Hastings.
- Topic: John is warning/complaining that life at Styles will be very quiet — little happening socially or excitingly.
- Where: As they turn in at the lodge gates of Styles Court, in the village of Styles St. Mary (just after arriving by train and driving through the surrounding country).
fragment: “I’m afraid you’ll find it very quiet down here, Hastings.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Captain Arthur Hastings (the narrator).
- Who is addressed: John (the companion who just spoke).
- What is the topic: Hastings is replying that he welcomes the quiet — he wants a peaceful, quiet stay.
- Where they are: arriving at the lodge gates of Styles Court in the village of Styles St. Mary, Essex (they have just turned in, arriving by motor car).
fragment: “My dear fellow, that’s just what I want.”

annotation:
Speaker: John (the host who greeted Hastings).  
Addressed to: Hastings (the narrator).  
Topic: John describes his active country life (drilling with the volunteers, helping on farms; his wife rising early to milk and working on the land), expresses annoyance with "that fellow Alfred Inglethorp," then checks the time and considers whether they can pick up Cynthia from the hospital but concludes she will already have left.  
Where: In their car, driving through the Essex countryside and turning in at the lodge gates of Styles Court, on a still July afternoon.
fragment:
“Oh, it’s pleasant enough if you want to lead the idle life. I drill
with the volunteers twice a week, and lend a hand at the farms. My wife
works regularly ‘on the land’. She is up at five every morning to milk,
and keeps at it steadily until lunchtime. It’s a jolly good life taking
it all round—if it weren’t for that fellow Alfred Inglethorp!” He
checked the car suddenly, and glanced at his watch. “I wonder if we’ve
time to pick up Cynthia. No, she’ll have started from the hospital by
now.”

annotation:
Speaker: Hastings (the guest who earlier replied "My dear fellow...").  
Addressed to: the other man in the scene — the host who checked the car and spoke about his wife and Alfred Inglethorp.  
Topic: Hastings's surprised question about Cynthia's relationship to the host — he is clarifying whether "Cynthia" (whom they were talking about picking up from the hospital) is the host's wife. It expresses surprise/confusion because the host had just spoken of "my wife" working on the land.  
Where: beside/inside the car in the countryside ("down here"), as they were preparing to drive to collect Cynthia from the hospital.
fragment: “Cynthia! That’s not your wife?”

hostility seemed to settle down upon the company. Miss Howard, in
particular, took no pains to conceal her feelings. Mrs. Inglethorp,

- Topic: The strained, awkward atmosphere at supper after a momentous event earlier that afternoon (the narrator has been anxious and worried about overheard words and about finding John; Mary Cavendish is implicated in whatever happened). Mr. Inglethorp’s uncharacteristic silence and Mrs. Inglethorp’s agitation are noted; normally he is demonstratively attentive to his wife, but tonight he is subdued.
- Where they are: In the Inglethorps' house — the supper/dining-room (with Mr. Inglethorp having been seen earlier in the drawing‑room) and Mrs. Inglethorp later retires to her boudoir.
fragment:
Mrs. Inglethorp came down last. She still looked agitated, and during
the meal there was a somewhat constrained silence. Inglethorp was
unusually quiet. As a rule, he surrounded his wife with little
attentions, placing a cushion at her back, and altogether playing the
part of the devoted husband. Immediately after supper, Mrs. Inglethorp
retired to her boudoir again.

annotation:
- Speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp (the hostess who just retired).
- Addressee: "Mary" — the household servant/maid (asking a servant to bring coffee).
- Topic: Asking for her coffee to be brought into her room because she has five minutes to catch the post (she's in a hurry to send something).
- Where: Mrs. Inglethorp's boudoir (she has just gone there after supper).
fragment:
“Send my coffee in here, Mary,” she called. “I’ve just five minutes to
catch the post.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The passage is narrated in first person by the unnamed narrator (“I”) who is a guest/observer in the Inglethorp household.
- Who is present / who is addressed: The narrator and Cynthia (another guest or companion) are sitting together; Mary Cavendish is a servant who brings coffee to them. No one is being directly addressed in this sentence (it is narrative). The phrase “She seemed excited” refers to Mary Cavendish.
- Topic: A brief scene-setting — the narrator and Cynthia sit by the open window in the drawing-room after supper; Mary brings their coffee and appears unusually excited. This follows the earlier moment when Mrs. Inglethorp retired to her boudoir to “catch the post,” so Mary’s excitement may be connected to that household event (e.g., news or a letter).
- Where: In the drawing-room (by the open window). For context, Mrs. Inglethorp is in her boudoir and Mr. Inglethorp remains in the drawing-room but was unusually quiet at supper.
fragment:
Cynthia and I went and sat by the open window in the drawing-room. Mary
Cavendish brought our coffee to us. She seemed excited.

annotation:
Speaker: Mary Cavendish, the servant who has just brought coffee and is described as excited.
Addressed to: "you young people" = the narrator ("I") and Cynthia; she then addresses Cynthia specifically to take the cup to Mrs. Inglethorp.
Topic: Asking whether the guests want the room lights or prefer to sit in the dusk (twilight), and offering to pour and send Mrs. Inglethorp's coffee.
Where: In the drawing-room (the narrator and Cynthia are by the open window); Mrs. Inglethorp is in her adjacent boudoir, having sent for her coffee just after supper.
fragment:
“Do you young people want lights, or do you enjoy the twilight?” she
asked. “Will you take Mrs. Inglethorp her coffee, Cynthia? I will pour
it out.”

annotation:
- Speaker: Mr. Inglethorp (referred to as "Inglethorp"), a man present in the room.
- Addressed to: Mary Cavendish, the house-servant who brought the coffee.
- Topic: Declining Mary's offer of help and taking responsibility for delivering the coffee to Emily (Mrs. Inglethorp).
- Where: The drawing-room (Cynthia and the narrator are sitting by the open window there); Inglethorp pours out the coffee in the room and then leaves carrying it to bring it to Emily.
fragment:
“Do not trouble, Mary,” said Inglethorp. “I will take it to Emily.” He
poured it out, and went out of the room carrying it carefully.

annotation:
Who is speaking: The narrator ("I") — this is a first‑person narrative reporting actions.

Who is addressed: No one is being spoken to in the fragment; it's a report to the reader. (Earlier, Mary Cavendish had spoken, but here there is no dialogue.)

Topic: Mr. Inglethorp has just poured coffee and gone out carrying it to Emily (referred to earlier as Mrs. Inglethorp); Lawrence (another man present) follows him out of the room. Mrs. Cavendish (Mary Cavendish) then sits down beside the narrator and Cynthia. The immediate subject is the serving of coffee and the people moving about and settling in.

Where they are: In the drawing‑room, sitting by the open window in the twilight (as established in the preceding lines).
fragment: Lawrence followed him, and Mrs. Cavendish sat down by us.

annotation:
Who is speaking: The passage is narrated in first person by the story's narrator (the "I" who has been present in the room).

Who is addressed: No one is being directly addressed in this sentence — it is descriptive narration to the reader.

Who is present / referenced: From the preceding lines we know the company includes Mrs. Cavendish (who has just sat down by the narrator), Cynthia (one of the young people just mentioned), Mr. Inglethorp (who poured out coffee and offered to take it to Emily), Lawrence (who followed Mr. Inglethorp out), Mary (the person who spoke earlier), and Emily (to whom the coffee was to be taken). In this fragment "we three" most naturally refers to the narrator, Cynthia, and Mrs. Cavendish.

Topic: The characters are sitting together in silence, noting the weather — a hot, still, glorious night — while Mrs. Cavendish fans herself with a palm leaf.

Where they are: Inside the same house and room where the earlier exchange took place (a drawing-room or sitting-room in the evening); two men (Inglethorp and Lawrence) have just left the room to take coffee to Emily, leaving the remaining three to sit indoors, near an open window or in the twilight.
fragment:
We three sat for some time in silence. It was a glorious night, hot and
still. Mrs. Cavendish fanned herself gently with a palm leaf.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Mrs. Cavendish (the "she" from the previous sentence).
- Who is addressed: a general remark to the others present in the room (the narrator and the other person forming "we three"), not a specific addressee.
- Topic: the weather — she is commenting that it is oppressively hot and predicting an approaching thunderstorm.
- Where: in the room where the three are sitting on a hot, still night; Mrs. Cavendish is fanning herself with a palm leaf.
fragment: “It’s almost too hot,” she murmured. “We shall have a thunderstorm.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first‑person narrator (one of the "we three" — the narrator, Lawrence, and Mrs. Cavendish).
- Who is addressed: Not another character — this is narrative/internal lamentation addressed to the reader.
- Topic: The narrator's peaceful enjoyment of the hot, still evening being abruptly broken by the arrival of a familiar, much‑disliked voice.
- Where they are: Inside the house on a hot night (they are sitting together; Mrs. Cavendish is fanning herself); the intrusive voice comes from the hall.
fragment:
Alas, that these harmonious moments can never endure! My paradise was
rudely shattered by the sound of a well known, and heartily disliked,
voice in the hall.

annotation:
Speaker: Cynthia (one of the three people described in the preceding lines).  
Addressed to: Dr. Bauerstein, who has just arrived or called from the hall.  
Topic: Cynthia's surprise at his unexpected arrival — she comments that it is an odd time to call (the hot, still night when they were relaxing), an arrival likely to interrupt the group's quiet evening.  
Where: Inside the house, at or near the hall/room where the three were sitting on a hot night (the narrator had just heard Dr. Bauerstein's voice in the hall).  
Additional context from the history: the narrator knows and "heartily disliked" Dr. Bauerstein, so the arrival is unwelcome to at least one person present.
fragment: “Dr. Bauerstein!” exclaimed Cynthia. “What a funny time to come.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first-person narrator (not Cynthia). This is an internal observation by the protagonist.
- Who is addressed: No one directly — the line describes the narrator's glance toward Mary Cavendish; it is narrative, not dialogue.
- What is the topic: The narrator's jealousy and irritation that Mary Cavendish remains calmly pale and unaffected when an unwelcome visitor (Dr. Bauerstein) has just arrived and disrupted the pleasant moment.
- Where they are: Inside a house, in the room adjacent to the hall (a sitting-room/drawing-room); Dr. Bauerstein's voice was heard in the hall moments earlier and Cynthia has just exclaimed at his arrival.
fragment:
I glanced jealously at Mary Cavendish, but she seemed quite
undisturbed, the delicate pallor of her cheeks did not vary.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The story is narrated in first person ("I"); here the narrator is describing events (third-person narration of the scene).
- Who is addressed: The arrival concerns Dr. Bauerstein, who Cynthia had just exclaimed over; Alfred Inglethorp ushers him in to the assembled company (including Cynthia, Mary Cavendish, and the narrator).
- What is the topic: Dr. Bauerstein's entrance — he is laughing and insisting he is unfit for a drawing-room because he is plastered with mud (i.e., very dirty).
- Where they are: In a house — the doctor was heard in the hall and is brought into the drawing-room by Alfred Inglethorp.
fragment:
In a few moments, Alfred Inglethorp had ushered the doctor in, the
latter laughing, and protesting that he was in no fit state for a
drawing-room. In truth, he presented a sorry spectacle, being literally
plastered with mud.

annotation:
Speaker: Mrs. Cavendish (Cynthia — the woman who earlier exclaimed “Dr. Bauerstein!”).
Addressee: Dr. Bauerstein (the doctor just ushered in by Alfred Inglethorp).
Topic: A reproach/question about the doctor’s dishevelled, mud‑spattered state — asking what he has been doing to be so dirty.
Location/context: In the Cavendish drawing‑room during a social visit; present are the narrator (“I”), Mary Cavendish, Alfred Inglethorp and the doctor. The doctor had just protested he was “in no fit state for a drawing‑room.”
fragment: “What have you been doing, doctor?” cried Mrs. Cavendish.

annotation:
- Speaker: the doctor — the mud‑splattered physician who has just been brought into the room.
- Addressed to: Mrs. Cavendish and the other people in the drawing‑room (he replies to Mrs. Cavendish’s question).
- Topic: a short apology for his intrusion and disordered appearance; he says he had not intended to come into the drawing‑room but came because Mr. Inglethorp insisted.
- Where: the Cavendish drawing‑room; Alfred Inglethorp had just ushered the doctor in, with Mary Cavendish and the narrator present.
fragment:
“I must make my apologies,” said the doctor. “I did not really mean to
come in, but Mr. Inglethorp insisted.”

annotation:
Speaker: John — a gentleman who has just entered from the hall (a member of the household or a visitor in the drawing-room).
Addressee: Bauerstein — the doctor who was just ushered in and is covered with mud (introduced in the preceding lines).
Topic: John comments on the doctor's disordered, muddy state, offers him coffee, and asks him to explain what he has been doing to get into that plight.
Location: the house drawing-room; John is coming in from the hall where Alfred Inglethorp had earlier brought the doctor.
fragment:
“Well, Bauerstein, you are in a plight,” said John, strolling in from
the hall. “Have some coffee, and tell us what you have been up to.”

annotation:
Speaker: Dr. Bauerstein (the "doctor" mentioned earlier).  
Addressed to: the people in the room — Mrs. Cavendish, John (and others present, including Mr. Inglethorp).  
Topic: He is explaining, with rueful laughter, that he found a rare fern in an inaccessible spot and, while trying to obtain it, lost his footing and fell into a nearby pond. He has just accepted John's offer of coffee and is telling how the mishap happened.  
Where: The conversation is taking place inside the Cavendish house (John has just entered from the hall). The fern incident itself happened outdoors at the pond.
fragment:
“Thank you, I will.” He laughed rather ruefully, as he described how he
had discovered a very rare species of fern in an inaccessible place,
and in his efforts to obtain it had lost his footing, and slipped
ignominiously into a neighbouring pond.

annotation: Speaker: Bauerstein. Addressees: the small group in the room (John, the doctor, and the others present, including Mr. Inglethorp). Topic: explaining his appearance after falling into a pond while trying to collect a rare fern — the sun dried him but he still looks untidy and bedraggled. Where: inside the house, in the room where the group has just gathered (John had just strolled in from the hall).
fragment:
“The sun soon dried me off,” he added, “but I’m afraid my appearance is
very disreputable.”

annotation:
Speaker: Mrs. Inglethorp, calling from the hall.
Addressee: Cynthia, a young woman present in the room.
Topic: Mrs. Inglethorp summons Cynthia (the reason is not given here), interrupting the conversation about Bauerstein’s mishap.
Where: The group is in a room adjoining the hall (a drawing-room/sitting-room); Cynthia runs out into the hall.
fragment:
At this juncture, Mrs. Inglethorp called to Cynthia from the hall, and
the girl ran out.

annotation:
Who is speaking: Mrs. Inglethorp (the woman who had just called to Cynthia).
Who is addressed: Cynthia (the girl Mrs. Inglethorp called from the hall).
Topic: A domestic request — Mrs. Inglethorp asks Cynthia to carry up her despatch-case because she is going to bed.
Where they are: In the house (the ground‑floor sitting room or anteroom near the hall); Mrs. Inglethorp is preparing to go up to bed and is speaking toward the hall where Cynthia had been.
fragment: “Just carry up my despatch-case, will you, dear? I’m going to bed.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator ("I") — a first‑person character recounting the scene.
- Who is addressed: No specific addressee in the scene; the narrator is telling the reader what happened.
- Topic: The narrator is recording that three people (the narrator, Cynthia, and John) were standing by the wide door into the hall and therefore could testify that Mrs. Inglethorp was carrying a cup of coffee, still untasted. This detail functions as an eyewitness/alibi about Mrs. Inglethorp's actions.
- Where: In a room opening onto the house hall (a wide doorway into the hall); Cynthia had just run into the hall after Mrs. Inglethorp called her (see the preceding lines).
fragment:
The door into the hall was a wide one. I had risen when Cynthia did,
John was close by me. There were therefore three witnesses who could
swear that Mrs. Inglethorp was carrying her coffee, as yet untasted, in
her hand.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first-person narrator of the story.
- Who is addressed: Not speaking to a character here; this is internal narration directed to the reader.
- What is the topic: The narrator is complaining that Dr. Bauerstein's presence ruined the evening because he stayed too long; the narrator feels relieved when Dr. Bauerstein finally rises to leave.
- Where they are: In Mrs. Inglethorp's house (evening), in the sitting-room/drawing-room area near the hall — Cynthia, John and Mrs. Inglethorp have just been mentioned as present nearby.
fragment:
My evening was utterly and entirely spoilt by the presence of Dr.
Bauerstein. It seemed to me the man would never go. He rose at last,
however, and I breathed a sigh of relief.

annotation:
- Speaker: Mr. Inglethorp (the husband of Mrs. Inglethorp).
- Addressees: first sentence is addressed to the person he proposes to accompany into the village (someone present in the room — likely Cynthia or the narrator who was about to go); the next line is addressed to John and to the household generally.
- Topic: he volunteers to walk into the village to see their estate agent about the accounts, and he reassures everyone that they need not stay up for him because he will take the latch‑key (i.e., he will lock up/return later).
- Where/scene: in the Inglethorps’ house, in the hall at the end of an evening visit (just after Dr. Bauerstein had left); the narrator, John and Mrs. Inglethorp are present.
fragment:
“I’ll walk down to the village with you,” said Mr. Inglethorp. “I must
see our agent over those estate accounts.” He turned to John. “No one
need sit up. I will take the latch-key.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Mr. Inglethorp.
- Who is addressed: first Dr. Bauerstein (offering to accompany him to the village), then John (when he says no one need sit up and that he will take the latch‑key).
- Topic: Mr. Inglethorp volunteers to walk down to the village to see their agent about estate accounts and tells John nobody need stay up because he will take the key.
- Where they are: in the hall by the wide door of the house, in the evening; present are the narrator, Cynthia, John, Mrs. Inglethorp (holding untasted coffee), Dr. Bauerstein and Mr. Inglethorp.

This is a chapter heading, not dialogue. It signals the narrator (the unnamed first‑person narrator in the history) is about to recount "the night of the tragedy." No one is speaking or being addressed in the fragment itself. Context from the preceding lines: the narrator is at home with Dr. Bauerstein (an unwelcome guest), Mr. Inglethorp, and John; it is evening, and Mr. Inglethorp has just offered to walk to the village to see their agent and take the latch‑key. The new chapter will describe events that happen that night at the house/estate.
fragment:
CHAPTER III.
THE NIGHT OF THE TRAGEDY

annotation:
- Speaker: the narrator, Captain Arthur Hastings ("I" in the story).
- Addressed to: the reader (Hastings is explaining to us).
- Topic: Hastings is adding a plan (floor plan) of the first floor of Styles to clarify the house layout. He points out that the servants’ rooms are reached via the door marked B on that plan and that those servants’ rooms have no internal communication with the right wing of the house — the right wing is where the Inglethorps’ rooms were located. This layout detail is given because it bears on the events of the "Night of the Tragedy."
- Where: at Styles Court, describing the first floor of the country house (the door B and the right wing refer to locations on that plan).
fragment:
To make this part of my story clear, I append the following plan of the
first floor of Styles. The servants’ rooms are reached through the door
B. They have no communication with the right wing, where the
Inglethorps’ rooms were situated.

annotation:
Speaker: the first‑person narrator (Captain Arthur Hastings) is inserting an illustration into his account. 
Addressee: the general reader. 
Topic: a floor plan of the first floor of Styles Court, provided to make clear the layout relevant to "the night of the tragedy" (shows the servants’ rooms reached through door B and the right wing where the Inglethorps’ rooms were). 
Location: Styles Court (the house where the murder/poisoning took place). 
Note: the fragment is an embedded illustration (a plan) rather than dialogue or narrative text; it supplements the preceding descriptive paragraph.
fragment: [Illustration]

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first‑person narrator — Captain Arthur Hastings, a guest at Styles Court.
- Who is addressed / acting in the scene: Lawrence Cavendish, a member of the Cavendish household, who has come to wake the narrator.
- Topic: An urgent nocturnal disturbance — the narrator is roused because something is seriously wrong (this opens the chapter called "The Night of the Tragedy").
- Where they are: In the narrator’s bedroom at Styles Court, the country house where the Cavendishes/Inglethorp family live (see the preceding plan of the first floor for the house layout).
fragment:
It seemed to be the middle of the night when I was awakened by Lawrence
Cavendish. He had a candle in his hand, and the agitation of his face
told me at once that something was seriously wrong.

annotation:
Speaker: the narrator (Captain Arthur Hastings).  
Addressed to: Lawrence Cavendish, who has just entered with a candle.  
Topic: a simple, urgent question—Hastings asks what has happened after being roused, trying to understand the disturbance.  
Where: in bed in his bedroom at Styles Court (first floor/right wing), in the middle of the night; Hastings is half-awake and disoriented, gathering his thoughts.
fragment:
“What’s the matter?” I asked, sitting up in bed, and trying to collect
my scattered thoughts.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Lawrence Cavendish (the man who woke the narrator).
- Who is addressed: the first‑person narrator (the person in bed whom Lawrence roused).
- Topic: Lawrence reports that his mother is seriously ill — possibly having a fit — and has locked herself in (presumably in a room), preventing immediate help.
- Where they are / context: it is the middle of the night; Lawrence stands at the narrator’s bedside holding a candle in the narrator’s bedroom, visibly agitated.
fragment:
“We are afraid my mother is very ill. She seems to be having some kind
of fit. Unfortunately she has locked herself in.”

annotation:
Speaker: the first-person narrator (the man who was awakened). 
Addressed to: Lawrence Cavendish, who has just come to the narrator’s bedroom holding a candle. 
Topic: the narrator is agreeing to go immediately to help — responding to Lawrence’s report that his mother is very ill and has locked herself in. 
Where: it is the middle of the night in the narrator’s bedroom; Lawrence has awakened him with the news.
fragment: “I’ll come at once.”

annotation:
Speaker: The first-person narrator ("I").  
Addressed to / who spoke before: Lawrence (the person who reported his mother being ill).  
Topic: Lawrence has come to tell the narrator that his (Lawrence's) mother appears to be having a fit and has locked herself in a room; the narrator is hurrying to assist.  
Where: They start in the narrator's bedroom (the narrator was in bed), then move along the passage and gallery into the right wing of the house — heading toward the part of the house where Lawrence's mother is locked in.
fragment:
I sprang out of bed; and, pulling on a dressing-gown, followed Lawrence
along the passage and the gallery to the right wing of the house.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrative voice ("I") is the first-person narrator describing events. Earlier lines quoted a messenger (a servant or household member) who said, "We are afraid my mother is very ill..." Lawrence also speaks or acts (he turns to his brother).
- Who is addressed: The messenger's warning is directed to Lawrence and the narrator (and others present). In the fragment Lawrence turns to address his brother, John Cavendish, who has just joined them.
- Topic: An urgent family medical emergency — their (or the messenger's) mother appears to be having a fit and has locked herself in a room; the household has rushed to help.
- Where they are: Inside the Cavendish family house. The narrator and Lawrence have run along a passage and the gallery to the right wing of the house; John and a few servants are gathered there in front of the affected room, in a state of alarm.
fragment:
John Cavendish joined us, and one or two of the servants were standing
round in a state of awe-stricken excitement. Lawrence turned to his
brother.

annotation:
Speaker: Lawrence (he has just "turned to his brother").
Addressed to: his brother, John Cavendish (who has joined them).
Topic: asking what course of action they should take in response to the alarming incident that has caused the servants' "awe-stricken excitement" — i.e., deciding what to do next.
Where: in the right wing of the house, in the passage/gallery, with the narrator, John, and a few servants gathered around.
fragment: “What do you think we had better do?”

annotation:
Who is speaking: The first-person narrator (an onlooker) is thinking this; it is an internal observation, not spoken aloud.

Who is addressed: No one — the line is the narrator's private thought. Immediately before, Lawrence had turned to his brother John Cavendish and asked, "What do you think we had better do?" so Lawrence was addressing John.

What is the topic: The narrator is commenting on Lawrence Cavendish's indecision — his inability to take charge or choose a course of action in the urgent situation that has alarmed the household.

Where are they: In the right wing of the house (along the passage and gallery), where John Cavendish, Lawrence, the narrator, and several servants have gathered in a state of excitement.
fragment: Never, I thought, had his indecision of character been more apparent.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: This is narrated in the first person by the story's narrator, but the sentence describes John Cavendish's actions. John Cavendish (Lawrence's brother) is the principal actor in the fragment.
- Who is addressed: John is responding to the urgent situation raised by Lawrence’s earlier question ("What do you think we had better do?"). The household — the narrator, Lawrence, John, and several servants — are present at the door; John is trying to open Mrs. Inglethorp’s room rather than speaking to an individual.
- Topic: The group hears alarming noises coming from inside Mrs. Inglethorp’s room and is attempting to gain entry. John tries rattling the locked/bolted door because something inside seems wrong and immediate action is required.
- Where: At the locked door of Mrs. Inglethorp’s room inside her house; the rest of the household (servants and the narrator) are assembled outside the room, alarmed. [[ ## completed ## ]]
fragment:
John rattled the handle of Mrs. Inglethorp’s door violently, but with
no effect. It was obviously locked or bolted on the inside. The whole
household was aroused by now. The most alarming sounds were audible
from the interior of the room. Clearly something must be done.

annotation:
Speaker: Dorcas — a servant/housemaid in the Inglethorp household.
Addressed to: "Sir" — the man trying the door (John, who had been rattling Mrs. Inglethorp’s door / the person in charge of deciding what to do).
Topic: She urges them to try entering the house by way of Mr. Inglethorp’s room as an alternative route to reach Mrs. Inglethorp, and expresses pity for the mistress ("the poor mistress") who is apparently in distress inside the locked room.
Location: Standing outside Mrs. Inglethorp’s locked door in the Inglethorp house (the household is roused and alarming sounds are coming from the room inside).
fragment:
“Try going through Mr. Inglethorp’s room, sir,” cried Dorcas. “Oh, the
poor mistress!”

annotation:
Who is speaking: The first‑person narrator ("I")—one of the people in the house observing events.
Who is present/mentioned: John (who opened the door and earlier rattled Mrs. Inglethorp’s door), Lawrence (following with a candle), Dorcas (a servant who earlier suggested checking Mr. Inglethorp’s room), Alfred (Mr.) Inglethorp (the man found to be absent), and Mrs. Inglethorp (the "poor mistress" mentioned earlier).
Who is addressed: No one is directly addressed in this fragment; it is the narrator reporting what they and the others see.
Topic: The discovery that Alfred (Mr.) Inglethorp is missing—his bedroom is dark, the bed appears unslept in, and there is no sign the room has been occupied, suggesting he was not there.
Where they are: In the Inglethorp house, at the door/inside of Alfred Inglethorp’s bedroom; the household has been aroused by alarm from Mrs. Inglethorp’s room and the small group is investigating.
fragment:
Suddenly I realized that Alfred Inglethorp was not with us—that he
alone had given no sign of his presence. John opened the door of his
room. It was pitch dark, but Lawrence was following with the candle,
and by its feeble light we saw that the bed had not been slept in, and
that there was no sign of the room having been occupied.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator ("I") — telling the story in first person about the group's actions.
- Who is meant by "we": The narrator and the household party searching the house (John, Lawrence, Dorcas and other servants who have been roused).
- Who is addressed: No one in particular; it's narrative description and a rhetorical question about their next action.
- Topic: The group has tried to reach Mrs. Inglethorp's room and is attempting to enter by the connecting door from Mr. Inglethorp's room, but that door is locked or bolted from the inside, leaving them uncertain what to do next.
- Where: Inside the Inglethorp house, at the interior/connecting door between Alfred (Mr.) Inglethorp's room and Mrs. Inglethorp's bedroom.
fragment:
We went straight to the connecting door. That, too, was locked or
bolted on the inside. What was to be done?

annotation:
Speaker: Dorcas, a housemaid/servant.
Addressee: "Sir" — the narrator (and by extension the small party present: John and Lawrence).
Topic: Urgent anxiety about what to do next — they have just found Mr. Alfred Inglethorp's room empty and a connecting door locked from the inside, and they are worried about the absent mistress and how to reach her.
Location: In the hallway/just outside Mr. Inglethorp's room and the connecting door between his room and the mistress's room in the house; John and Lawrence are with the narrator and Dorcas.
fragment:
“Oh, dear, sir,” cried Dorcas, wringing her hands, “what ever shall we
do?”

annotation:
Speaker: one of the men in the group (probably John or the narrator) who has just opened Alfred Inglethorp’s room.
Addressed to: the other members present — chiefly Dorcas and the household servants/maids — and to the rest of the men standing by.
Topic: proposing to break open the locked/bolted connecting door to Miss Cynthia’s rooms; instructing a maid to go and wake Baily and send him to fetch Dr. Wilkins; preparing to attempt forcing the door.
Where: inside the house, at the connecting door between Alfred Inglethorp’s room (where they have just found the bed unslept in) and Miss Cynthia’s rooms, by candlelight in a dark corridor/room.
fragment:
“We must try and break the door in, I suppose. It’ll be a tough job,
though. Here, let one of the maids go down and wake Baily and tell him
to go for Dr. Wilkins at once. Now then, we’ll have a try at the door.
Half a moment, though, isn’t there a door into Miss Cynthia’s rooms?”

annotation:
Speaker: Dorcas, one of the maids (she was named and seen wringing her hands in the previous line).  
Addressed to: "Sir" — the gentleman who just suggested trying the doors / breaking the connecting door (the person in charge of the group).  
Topic: Whether there is an alternate door into Miss Cynthia’s rooms — Dorcas says that alternate door is always bolted and has never been opened, so it cannot be used.  
Location/context: They are inside the house at the connecting door between rooms (trying to get into Miss Cynthia’s rooms); earlier they found the connecting door locked/bolted and were considering other entrances and sending for Dr. Wilkins.
fragment: “Yes, sir, but that’s always bolted. It’s never been undone.”

annotation:

Addressee: the maid who just said the inner door to Miss Cynthia’s rooms is always bolted (i.e., the household servants, including Dorcas).

fragment: “Well, we might just see.”

annotation:

there, shaking the girl—who must have been an unusually sound
sleeper—and trying to wake her.

annotation: Narrative line. "He" is the unnamed man who earlier said "Well, we might just see." He had run to Cynthia's room, where Mary Cavendish was trying to wake the sleeping girl. one is a shade less solid than the one in the passage.”

annotation:

We strained and heaved together. The framework of the door was solid,
and for a long time it resisted our efforts, but at last we felt it
give beneath our weight, and finally, with a resounding crash, it was
burst open.

fragment:
We stumbled in together, Lawrence still holding his candle. Mrs.
Inglethorp was lying on the bed, her whole form agitated by violent
convulsions, in one of which she must have overturned the table beside
her. As we entered, however, her limbs relaxed, and she fell back upon
the pillows.

annotation:

- Where: In Mrs. Inglethorp's bedroom in the house; Annie is sent down to the dining‑room, and there is a door leading onto the corridor that the narrator unbolts.
fragment:
John strode across the room, and lit the gas. Turning to Annie, one of
the housemaids, he sent her downstairs to the dining-room for brandy.
Then he went across to his mother whilst I unbolted the door that gave
on the corridor.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator, first-person "I" (one of the men who forced open the door).
- Who is addressed / present: The narrator had just turned to Lawrence (one of the companions) intending to suggest he leave; others in the room include Lawrence, John (who lit the gas), Annie the housemaid (sent downstairs), and Mrs. Inglethorp, who lies on the bed.

- Where / context: Inside Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedroom or sick-room immediately after they burst the locked door and entered; gas has been lit and a candle is held by Lawrence. The mood is tense and eerie.
fragment:
I turned to Lawrence, to suggest that I had better leave them now that
there was no further need of my services, but the words were frozen on
my lips. Never have I seen such a ghastly look on any man’s face. He
was white as chalk, the candle he held in his shaking hand was
sputtering onto the carpet, and his eyes, petrified with terror, or
some such kindred emotion, stared fixedly over my head at a point on
the further wall. It was as though he had seen something that turned
him to stone. I instinctively followed the direction of his eyes, but I
could see nothing unusual. The still feebly flickering ashes in the
grate, and the row of prim ornaments on the mantelpiece, were surely
harmless enough.

annotation:
Speaker: the story’s first‑person narrator (the observer who has just entered the room).
Addressed to: the reader — this is narrative description, not dialogue directed at another character.
Topic: Mrs. Inglethorp’s violent convulsive attack is easing; she is beginning to speak again in short, broken gasps.
Where: Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedroom/bedchamber in the house where the narrator, Lawrence (holding a candle), John (her son, who has lit the gas), and the maid Annie (sent for brandy) are gathered; the scene follows their recent entrance and the unbolting of the corridor door.
fragment:
The violence of Mrs. Inglethorp’s attack seemed to be passing. She was
able to speak in short gasps.

annotation:

fragment: “Better now—very sudden—stupid of me—to lock myself in.”

annotation:

- Where they are: In the same room as the earlier scene — a bedroom (there is a bed, a grate/fireplace and a mantelpiece) where Mrs. Inglethorp had her attack.
fragment:
A shadow fell on the bed and, looking up, I saw Mary Cavendish standing
near the door with her arm around Cynthia. She seemed to be supporting
the girl, who looked utterly dazed and unlike herself. Her face was
heavily flushed, and she yawned repeatedly.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Mrs. Cavendish (Mary Cavendish).
- Who is addressed: the people in the room — the narrator (first person "I"), Mrs. Inglethorp (the patient in bed), and Cynthia — i.e., a general remark to those present.

- Where they are: in Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedroom/sickroom; the narrator notes Mrs. Cavendish’s white land smock and a faint streak of daylight, and the mantel clock shows close to five o’clock (so it is later than the narrator first thought).
fragment:
“Poor Cynthia is quite frightened,” said Mrs. Cavendish in a low clear
voice. She herself, I noticed, was dressed in her white land smock.
Then it must be later than I thought. I saw that a faint streak of
daylight was showing through the curtains of the windows, and that the
clock on the mantelpiece pointed to close upon five o’clock.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first‑person narrator (an onlooker present in the room) is describing what he sees.

- Where they are: In the old lady’s bedchamber (a room with a bed, mantelpiece and curtains) at the Cavendish house, shortly before five o’clock with daylight beginning to show through the windows.
fragment:
A strangled cry from the bed startled me. A fresh access of pain seized
the unfortunate old lady. The convulsions were of a violence terrible
to behold. Everything was confusion. We thronged round her, powerless
to help or alleviate. A final convulsion lifted her from the bed, until
she appeared to rest upon her head and her heels, with her body arched
in an extraordinary manner. In vain Mary and John tried to administer
more brandy. The moments flew. Again the body arched itself in that
peculiar fashion.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The passage is narrated by the first-person observer ("I"); the only vocal action in the fragment is a strangled cry from Mrs. Inglethorp (the old lady who has been suffering convulsions).

fragment:
At that moment, Dr. Bauerstein pushed his way authoritatively into the
room. For one instant he stopped dead, staring at the figure on the
bed, and, at the same instant, Mrs. Inglethorp cried out in a strangled
voice, her eyes fixed on the doctor:

annotation:

- Where they are: In the sickroom/bedroom where the injured old lady lies (just before dawn, about five o’clock); others present include Dr. Bauerstein (who has just entered), Mrs. Cavendish, Mary and John.
fragment: “Alfred—Alfred——” Then she fell back motionless on the pillows.

annotation:

fragment:
With a stride, the doctor reached the bed, and seizing her arms worked
them energetically, applying what I knew to be artificial respiration.
He issued a few short sharp orders to the servants. An imperious wave
of his hand drove us all to the door. We watched him, fascinated,
though I think we all knew in our hearts that it was too late, and that
nothing could be done now. I could see by the expression on his face
that he himself had little hope.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: A first‑person narrator (one of the people present in the room), reporting the scene.
- Who is addressed: Nobody in the fragment — the line is narrative description addressed to the reader.
- What is the topic: Dr. Bauerstein (the doctor who had been performing artificial respiration) ceases his attempt to revive Mrs. Inglethorp, shaking his head in resignation; immediately afterward Dr. Wilkins, Mrs. Inglethorp’s own physician (described as a portly, fussy little man), arrives.
- Where are they: At Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedside in her bedroom (the narrator and other household members are standing by the door; Dr. Wilkins comes in from outside the room/hallway).

Finally he abandoned his task, shaking his head gravely. At that
moment, we heard footsteps outside, and Dr. Wilkins, Mrs. Inglethorp’s
own doctor, a portly, fussy little man, came bustling in.

In a few words Dr. Bauerstein explained how he had happened to be
passing the lodge gates as the car came out, and had run up to the
house as fast as he could, whilst the car went on to fetch Dr. Wilkins.
With a faint gesture of the hand, he indicated the figure on the bed.

annotation:

- Where they are: at Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedside in the house/lodge, immediately after the failed resuscitation attempt by Dr. Bauerstein.
fragment:
“Ve—ry sad. Ve—ry sad,” murmured Dr. Wilkins. “Poor dear lady. Always
did far too much—far too much—against my advice. I warned her. Her
heart was far from strong. ‘Take it easy,’ I said to her,
‘Take—it—easy’. But no—her zeal for good works was too great. Nature
rebelled. Na—ture—re—belled.”

annotation:

Dr. Bauerstein, I noticed, was watching the local doctor narrowly. He
still kept his eyes fixed on him as he spoke.

turned to John. “You do not object?”

and I heard the key turned in the lock behind us.

We went slowly down the stairs. I was violently excited. I have a
certain talent for deduction, and Dr. Bauerstein’s manner had started a
flock of wild surmises in my mind. Mary Cavendish laid her hand upon my
arm.

voice to a whisper. “I believe she has been poisoned! I’m certain Dr.

“_What?_” She shrank against the wall, the pupils of her eyes dilating
wildly. Then, with a sudden cry that startled me, she cried out: “No,
no—not that—not that!” And breaking from me, fled up the stairs. I
followed her, afraid that she was going to faint. I found her leaning
against the bannisters, deadly pale. She waved me away impatiently.

looking important and excited, and trying to conceal an inward
exultation under a manner of decorous calm. Dr. Bauerstein remained in

CHAPTER IV.
POIROT INVESTIGATES

annotation:

The house which the Belgians occupied in the village was quite close to
the park gates. One could save time by taking a narrow path through the
long grass, which cut off the detours of the winding drive. So I,
accordingly, went that way. I had nearly reached the lodge, when my
attention was arrested by the running figure of a man approaching me.
It was Mr. Inglethorp. Where had he been? How did he intend to explain
his absence?
