Speaker: the first-person narrator (Captain Hastings), addressing the reader.
Addressee: the reader/audience; implicitly speaking to himself and Poirot as he narrates past events.
Topic: Hastings and Hercule Poirot are going to inspect the scene of the crime — "the room of the tragedy" means the room in which the death/murder occurred. Hastings also notes he will include a floor plan of the room and its main furniture for the reader's convenience.
Where: upstairs in the house where the incident took place; they are going up to the victim’s room to examine it together. This follows the brief exchange about Dr. Bauerstein and Poirot’s concluding remark that the matter is simplified.
fragment:
We went up together to the room of the tragedy. For convenience I
append a plan of the room and the principal articles of furniture in
it.

annotation:
- Speaker: Hercule Poirot (the detective).  
- Addressee: the narrator (Hastings) and those present — Poirot is commenting aloud to the small party.  
- Topic: Poirot remarks that "he" (a suspect or witness referenced earlier) is very sure about something, which Poirot says simplifies the investigation; immediately afterward Poirot and the narrator go to examine the scene of the crime.  
- Location/context: they have gone up to the room where the tragedy (the murder) occurred. The fragment "[Illustration]" signals that the book is inserting a plan/diagram of that room and its principal articles of furniture for the reader's reference (the narrator says he appends this plan "for convenience").
fragment: [Illustration]

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first-person narrator, Captain Arthur Hastings (a friend and companion of Poirot), is narrating the scene.
- Who is addressed: This is narrative directed to the reader (not a line of dialogue to another character).
- What is the topic: Hercule Poirot is conducting a careful, rapid inspection of the room where the tragedy (a murder) took place. The narrator stands by the door to avoid disturbing clues; Poirot locks the door from the inside and seems ungrateful for the narrator's restraint.
- Where they are: In the "room of the tragedy" — the bedroom at Styles Court (upstairs in the house), previously introduced in the plan appended just before this passage.
fragment:
Poirot locked the door on the inside, and proceeded to a minute
inspection of the room. He darted from one object to the other with the
agility of a grasshopper. I remained by the door, fearing to obliterate
any clues. Poirot, however, did not seem grateful to me for my
forbearance.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot.  
Addressee: the narrator (the companion who is standing by the door — in Christie this is Captain Hastings).  
Topic: Poirot is chiding/teasing him for standing frozen and not helping with the examination — calling him "like the stuck pig" (i.e., motionless).  
Where: inside the locked "room of the tragedy" — the crime scene that Poirot has just locked and is inspecting.
fragment:
“What have you, my friend,” he cried, “that you remain there like—how
do you say it?—ah, yes, the stuck pig?”

annotation:
- Speaker: "I" is the story's narrator (Captain Hastings, Poirot's companion).
- Addressee: He is speaking to Hercule Poirot.
- Topic: He is explaining why he stayed by the door — to avoid obliterating foot-marks (footprints) on the floor, which are potential evidence.
- Where: Inside the locked room that Poirot has sealed and is now carefully inspecting (the crime-scene they are examining).
fragment: I explained that I was afraid of obliterating any foot-marks.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot, the detective.  
Addressed to: The narrator (Captain Hastings), who had been standing by the door.  
Topic: Poirot dismisses Hastings's concern about preserving foot-marks—saying many people have already been in the room so footprints are unlikely to be useful—and asks Hastings to join him in searching the room for other clues. He also notes he will set down his little detective case.  
Where: Inside the locked room (the crime scene) that Poirot has just been inspecting.
fragment:
“Foot-marks? But what an idea! There has already been practically an
army in the room! What foot-marks are we likely to find? No, come here
and aid me in my search. I will put down my little case until I need
it.”

annotation: "He" refers to Sherlock Holmes; "I" is Dr. John Watson (the narrator). Holmes is speaking to Watson, dismissing Watson's worry about "foot-marks" and asking him to help search the room. The scene takes place in the room they are investigating (the crime scene); Holmes sets down his "little case" (the despatch-case) on a round table by the window, but because the table-top was loose it tilted and the case fell to the floor.
fragment:
He did so, on the round table by the window, but it was an ill-advised
proceeding; for, the top of it being loose, it tilted up, and
precipitated the despatch-case on the floor.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot (the detective).
Addressed to: the narrator (the "I" from the history), i.e., his companion (Captain Hastings).
Topic: Poirot is remarking—half humorously, half exasperatedly—on the poor, uncomfortable furniture (the loose-topped round table) that has just caused the despatch-case to fall; he contrasts living in a "big house" with the lack of comfort in its appointments.
Where: in the room they are searching in a large house (by the window, at the round table mentioned just before).  
Note: The French phrase "Eh voilà une table!" roughly means "There — a table!" or "Ah, here is a table!" and underscores his annoyed amusement.
fragment:
“_Eh voilà une table!_” cried Poirot. “Ah, my friend, one may live in a
big house and yet have no comfort.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator (Hastings) is narrating; the sentence refers to Hercule Poirot.
- Who is addressed: Poirot had been addressing his friend (the narrator) with "Ah, my friend..."
- What is the topic: Poirot's short moralizing about the uncomfortable table and lack of comfort after the despatch-case fell, then he returns to searching the room for foot‑marks/clues.
- Where are they: In a room of the big house (by a round table near the window) where they are examining the scene.
fragment: After which piece of moralizing, he resumed his search.

annotation:
Speaker: The passage is narrated by "me" — Captain Hastings. The pronoun "he" refers to Hercule Poirot.  
Addressee: Poirot hands the key to Hastings for inspection (no one else is being addressed in this line).  
Topic: A small purple despatch-case and its key — Hastings inspects the key, which is described as an ordinary Yale-type key with a bit of twisted wire through its handle; nothing unusual is found.  
Where: On the writing-table in the room of the large house where Poirot and Hastings are searching (earlier the same despatch-case had been upset from the round table by the window).
fragment:
A small purple despatch-case, with a key in the lock, on the
writing-table, engaged his attention for some time. He took out the key
from the lock, and passed it to me to inspect. I saw nothing peculiar,
however. It was an ordinary key of the Yale type, with a bit of twisted
wire through the handle.

annotation:
Speaker: "He" is Hercule Poirot; the first-person "I" is the narrator (Captain Hastings) addressing the reader.  
Topic: Poirot is carrying out a close forensic inspection of doors in the house—confirming that a previously broken-in door had its bolt shot, then unbolting and testing the door into Cynthia’s room. Noticing something on the bolt itself, he uses small forceps from his case to remove a minute particle and seals it in a tiny envelope as evidence.  
Location: inside the same house, at the doorframe opposite the writing-table, the door that leads into Cynthia’s room (they had earlier forced entry into another door nearby).
fragment:
Next, he examined the framework of the door we had broken in, assuring
himself that the bolt had really been shot. Then he went to the door
opposite leading into Cynthia’s room. That door was also bolted, as I
had stated. However, he went to the length of unbolting it, and opening
and shutting it several times; this he did with the utmost precaution
against making any noise. Suddenly something in the bolt itself seemed
to rivet his attention. He examined it carefully, and then, nimbly
whipping out a pair of small forceps from his case, he drew out some
minute particle which he carefully sealed up in a tiny envelope.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator, Dr. John H. Watson.
- Who is addressed: The narration is directed to the reader (it continues Watson’s account of the investigation alongside Sherlock Holmes).
- What is the topic: A description of objects found on a chest of drawers — a tray holding a spirit lamp and small saucepan containing a little dark liquid, plus an empty cup and saucer that had just been drunk from (i.e., evidence someone had recently heated and consumed a dark liquid).
- Where they are: In the room they had just unbolted and inspected — Cynthia’s room (the door opposite that had been examined and opened moments before).
fragment:
On the chest of drawers there was a tray with a spirit lamp and a small
saucepan on it. A small quantity of a dark fluid remained in the
saucepan, and an empty cup and saucer that had been drunk out of stood
near it.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator "I" is Dr. James Sheppard (the story's first‑person narrator).
- Who is addressed: This is an internal remark by Dr. Sheppard (not spoken to anyone), though Hercule Poirot is physically present and acting in the scene.
- Topic: They have found a new clue — a dark liquid remaining in a small saucepan and a used cup on a tray. Poirot tests the liquid by tasting it (presumably to identify it or detect poison) and reacts with a grimace.
- Where they are: In the bedroom they have just inspected/unbolted (the room with the chest of drawers and tray — the room that was identified as Cynthia’s room in the preceding lines).
fragment:
I wondered how I could have been so unobservant as to overlook this.
Here was a clue worth having. Poirot delicately dipped his finger into
liquid, and tasted it gingerly. He made a grimace.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot. He is speaking aloud to the narrator (Captain Hastings/the "I" of the story).  
Topic: identifying the dark liquid left in the saucepan and cup—Poirot concludes it is cocoa with rum.  
Location: in Cynthia’s bedroom, at the chest of drawers where a tray with a spirit lamp, saucepan and an emptied cup were found.  
Context: they are investigating the room for clues; Poirot had just tasted the residue from the saucepan and grimaced before making this remark.
fragment: “Cocoa—with—I think—rum in it.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The passage is narrated in first person by the narrator ("I") — the companion of Poirot (the usual narrator, Captain Hastings).
- Who "He" refers to: Hercule Poirot is the one moving about and examining the scene.
- Who is addressed: No one in-scene is being directly addressed; this is narrative description for the reader.
- What is the topic: Poirot inspects the debris from an overturned bedside table — noting a reading-lamp, books, matches, keys, and fragments of a crushed coffee-cup.
- Where they are: In the bedroom, at the bedside (the table by the bed has been overturned), searching the room for clues.
fragment:
He passed on to the debris on the floor, where the table by the bed had
been overturned. A reading-lamp, some books, matches, a bunch of keys,
and the crushed fragments of a coffee-cup lay scattered about.

annotation:
- Speaker: Hercule Poirot (the detective).
- Addressee: the story's narrator ("I") and any others present (he is speaking aloud to the people in the room).
- Topic: Poirot is remarking on the small but significant clues he has just examined — the cocoa with rum he tasted and the scattered debris from the overturned bedside table (reading-lamp, books, matches, keys, broken coffee-cup).
- Location: at the scene of the disturbance, beside the bed in the bedroom where the table has been overturned (a crime scene in the room being inspected).
fragment: “Ah, this is curious,” said Poirot.

annotation:
Speaker: Captain Arthur Hastings (the narrator and Poirot's companion).
Addressed to: Hercule Poirot.
Topic: A remark about the overturned table and scattered debris (reading-lamp, books, keys, crushed coffee-cup) that Poirot has just called "curious"; the speaker expresses skepticism and says he finds nothing unusual.
Location: In the bedroom/crime scene where the table by the bed has been overturned and the debris lies on the floor.
fragment: “I must confess that I see nothing particularly curious about it.”

annotation:
- Speaker: Hercule Poirot (he is the one saying "You do not? Observe the lamp...")
- Addressee: the companion who just replied "I must confess..." (the narrator/assistant present at the scene)
- Topic: Poirot is pointing out physical evidence in the wreckage — the broken lamp chimney (pieces lying where they fell) and the coffee-cup completely smashed — as items of interest in an apparent disturbance.
- Location: at the bedside in the room where an overturned bedside/table lies; they are examining debris scattered on the floor (reading lamp, books, matches, keys, and cup fragments).
fragment:
“You do not? Observe the lamp—the chimney is broken in two places; they
lie there as they fell. But see, the coffee-cup is absolutely smashed
to powder.”

annotation:
Speaker: "I" — the story's narrator (Hastings) — speaking to Hercule Poirot.  
Addressee: Poirot.  
Topic: a terse explanation for the smashed coffee-cup (Hastings suggests it was stepped on).  
Where: in the room they are examining — the scene where the lamp chimney is broken and the cup lies in pieces on the floor. The remark is weary/half-dismissive.
fragment: “Well,” I said wearily, “I suppose someone must have stepped on it.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot, the detective.
- Who is addressed: the narrator ("I"), Captain Hastings, who has been inspecting the broken items.
- What is the topic: confirming the earlier remark about the broken lamp chimney and the coffee-cup being smashed — the deduction that someone stepped on the cup.
- Where they are: at the scene where the lamp and coffee-cup lie broken — the room they are examining (the immediate surroundings of the smashed items).
fragment: “Exactly,” said Poirot, in an odd voice. “Someone stepped on it.”

annotation:
Who is "he": Hercule Poirot (the detective).
Who is present/being addressed: The narrator ("I", likely Captain Hastings) — Poirot is interacting with the narrator and the others in the room.
Topic: Poirot is examining the scene (the broken lamp chimney and the smashed coffee-cup) and is reacting to his own deduction that "someone stepped on it."
Where: In the room where the breakage occurred — by the mantelpiece/fireplace in the drawing-room or sitting-room; Poirot rises from his knees at the scene and fidgets with the ornaments (a habitual gesture when he's agitated).
fragment:
He rose from his knees, and walked slowly across to the mantelpiece,
where he stood abstractedly fingering the ornaments, and straightening
them—a trick of his when he was agitated.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot (addressing the narrator, "I" — Dr. Hastings).  
Addressee: the narrator/Hastings ("Mon ami" = "my friend").  
Topic: a cup that has been crushed to powder; Poirot is explaining that someone deliberately stepped on the cup either because it contained strychnine (poison) or — more worryingly — because it did not contain strychnine (implicating a different, more serious motive).  
Where: in the room where they are examining the broken cup (Poirot has just risen from his knees and walked to the mantelpiece, i.e. at the scene being inspected).  
Tone/gesture: Poirot speaks in an odd, agitated voice and is fingering/straightening ornaments on the mantelpiece as he talks.
fragment:
“_Mon ami_,” he said, turning to me, “somebody stepped on that cup,
grinding it to powder, and the reason they did so was either because it
contained strychnine or—which is far more serious—because it did not
contain strychnine!”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator, Captain Arthur Hastings ("I"), who is giving a first-person account.
- Who is being addressed / to whom: He is not speaking to anyone here; he is reacting silently to Hercule Poirot's remarks and actions. Poirot is the other person present and the active investigator.
- What is the topic: Poirot's continuing investigation into the smashed cup (and the question of strychnine). He examines a bunch of keys, selects a bright one, opens a purple despatch-case (presumably containing papers or evidence), hesitates, then closes it and pockets several keys — including the key originally in the lock.
- Where they are: In the room with the mantelpiece at Styles Court (the room where the broken cup and the subsequent investigation are taking place).
fragment:
I made no reply. I was bewildered, but I knew that it was no good
asking him to explain. In a moment or two he roused himself, and went
on with his investigations. He picked up the bunch of keys from the
floor, and twirling them round in his fingers finally selected one,
very bright and shining, which he tried in the lock of the purple
despatch-case. It fitted, and he opened the box, but after a moment’s
hesitation, closed and relocked it, and slipped the bunch of keys, as
well as the key that had originally stood in the lock, into his own
pocket.

annotation:
Who is speaking: "He" — Sherlock Holmes (the investigator who earlier said "Mon ami" and was handling the mantelpiece ornaments and the keys).

Who is addressed: "me" — Dr. John H. Watson, the narrator and Holmes's companion.

What is the topic: Holmes is insisting that they must examine the papers contained in the purple despatch-case at once. He admits they have no legal authority to search them, but considers it necessary for the investigation (connected to the crushed cup and the question of poison).

Where they are: In the room they are examining as part of their inquiry (the room with the mantelpiece, the crushed cup, and the purple despatch-case whose lock Holmes just tried and briefly opened).
fragment:
“I have no authority to go through these papers. But it should be
done—at once!”

annotation:
- Who is "he": Sherlock Holmes. The preceding lines show Holmes speaking ("Mon ami") and then returning to his investigations; the "he" in this fragment continues to refer to him.
- Who is present / who is addressed: Dr. John Watson is the narrator and observer ("me" in the history). The fragment is not direct speech addressed to anyone; it describes Holmes's actions as Watson watches.
- Topic: Holmes is continuing his forensic search for evidence connected with the smashed cup and possible poison. He examines the wash-stand drawers for relevant objects and inspects a faint round stain on the dark brown carpet (kneeling to examine and even smell it) to determine its nature — e.g., residue, blood, or chemical traces.
- Where: In the same room already being searched (the victim's room where the cup was found crushed), near the left-hand window on a dark brown carpet. [[ ## completed ## ]]
fragment:
He then made a very careful examination of the drawers of the
wash-stand. Crossing the room to the left-hand window, a round stain,
hardly visible on the dark brown carpet, seemed to interest him
particularly. He went down on his knees, examining it minutely—even
going so far as to smell it.

annotation:
Who is speaking: "He" — the male investigator/chemist who has been examining the room (not the narrator).  
Who is addressed: No direct addressee in this sentence; the action is performed by the investigator in front of the narrator ("I"), who is present and observing.  
What is the topic: The investigator is carrying out a chemical test on a substance (a sample of cocoa or of material associated with the stain) and preparing to record his observations — pouring a few drops into a test tube and taking out a small notebook to make notes.  
Where they are: In the room they have been searching (near the wash-stand and the left-hand window, on the dark brown carpet) — i.e., the lodging/bedroom they are investigating.
fragment:
Finally, he poured a few drops of the cocoa into a test tube, sealing
it up carefully. His next proceeding was to take out a little notebook.

annotation:
Speaker: the investigator who has just been examining the room (the "he" from the previous lines — the detective).
Addressee: his companion/narrator (the person with him in the room, to whom he is speaking).
Topic: the detective's findings — he says there are six points of interest in the room and asks whether he should list them or let the companion do so.
Where: in the room they have been searching (the room with the wash-stand, the dark brown carpet with a round stain, and the cocoa sample just poured into a test tube). He is writing busily in his notebook as he speaks.
fragment:
“We have found in this room,” he said, writing busily, “six points of
interest. Shall I enumerate them, or will you?”

annotation:
Who is speaking: The first-person narrator ("I") — Dr. Watson.
Who is addressed: The detective (Sherlock Holmes), who has just offered to enumerate "six points of interest."
What is the topic: Holmes's offer to list the six points of interest (the evidence found in the room — e.g., the stain on the carpet, the cocoa sample, the wash-stand drawers).
Where are they: In the room under investigation (near the left-hand window and wash-stand, on the dark brown carpet). The narrator's reply is hurried ("hastily"), showing a quick, possibly embarrassed or impatient reaction.
fragment: “Oh, you,” I replied hastily.

annotation:
Speaker: "He" — the man who was pouring cocoa and writing in the little notebook (the detective figure from the preceding lines; in context the investigator narratively addressing his companion).  
Addressed to: "I" — the narrator/companion (the person who replied "Oh, you").  
Topic: The speaker is enumerating points of interest/evidence found in the room: (1) a coffee-cup ground into powder, (2) a despatch-case with a key in the lock, (3) a stain on the floor.  
Location: They are inside the room under investigation (the room mentioned earlier — the scene they are examining).

Speaker: "he" is Sherlock Holmes (the detective), who is writing notes; "I" is Dr. John Watson (the narrator). Holmes is addressing Watson ("you"). Topic: Holmes is listing points of interest — pieces of evidence found in the room (a coffee-cup ground to powder, a despatch-case with a key in the lock, and a stain on the floor among others) — and Watson interrupts to say that the stain may have been made earlier. Location: they are standing in the room under investigation (a scene they are examining), with Holmes taking notes.
fragment: “That may have been done some time ago,” I interrupted.

annotation:
Speaker: Sherlock Holmes (the man enumerating clues).  
Addressed to: "I" — Dr. John Watson, the narrator, who had just interrupted.  
Topic: Holmes is listing and interpreting physical clues found at the scene — a recently used coffee-cup (still damp, smelling of coffee), a despatch-case with a key, a stain on the floor, and a tiny fragment of dark green fabric.  
Where: In the room they are examining during an investigation (the immediate scene — a sitting-room/study where the evidence was found).
fragment:
“No, for it is still perceptibly damp and smells of coffee. Four, a
fragment of some dark green fabric—only a thread or two, but
recognizable.”

annotation:
Who is speaking: the first-person narrator ("I") — the companion/narrator typical of Holmes stories (Dr. Watson) — exclaims.

Who is addressed: the detective who has been listing the items (Sherlock Holmes).

Topic: a sudden realization that one of the items Holmes described (specifically the small fragment/thread of dark green fabric mentioned in the previous line) is the thing Holmes had sealed in an envelope.

Where they are: in the room where they are reviewing the evidence together (the familiar sitting-room/study where Holmes and the narrator discuss cases).
fragment: “Ah!” I cried. “That was what you sealed up in the envelope.”

annotation:
Who is speaking: Sherlock Holmes (referred to as "he" in the preceding lines).
Who is addressed: Dr. John Watson, the narrator ("I") — they are discussing the scene together.
Topic: Holmes continues to enumerate and interpret physical evidence found in the room (a possible fragment of Mrs. Inglethorp’s dress, and a fresh-looking splash of candle grease). He infers the grease must be recent because a competent housemaid would have removed it, and he adds a brief personal anecdote about losing a hat.
Where: In a room of Mrs. Inglethorp’s house — specifically by the writing-table where they are inspecting the floor and other clues.
fragment:
“Yes. It may turn out to be a piece of one of Mrs. Inglethorp’s own
dresses, and quite unimportant. We shall see. Five, _this_!” With a
dramatic gesture, he pointed to a large splash of candle grease on the
floor by the writing-table. “It must have been done since yesterday,
otherwise a good housemaid would have at once removed it with
blotting-paper and a hot iron. One of my best hats once—but that is not
to the point.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Dr. John H. Watson (the narrator).
- Who is addressed: Sherlock Holmes (Watson is replying to Holmes's remark and looking at the same clue).
- Topic: They are discussing the large splash of candle grease on the floor by the writing-table — whether it was made the previous night and whether Mrs. Inglethorp herself might have dropped the candle amid the household agitation.
- Where they are: In Mrs. Inglethorp’s room (by the writing-table), examining clues in her house.
fragment:
“It was very likely done last night. We were very agitated. Or perhaps
Mrs. Inglethorp herself dropped her candle.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Sherlock Holmes (the man who just pointed out the grease and made the "Five, this!" remark).
- Who is addressed: the narrator ("I" — Dr. Watson), who has just said they were agitated and suggested Mrs. Inglethorp might have dropped her candle.
- Topic: Holmes is asking about how many candles were brought into the room earlier — a question intended to explain the large splash of candle-grease on the floor and whether a dropped candle could account for it.
- Where they are: in Mrs. Inglethorp's room, by the writing-table, examining the candle-grease stain on the floor.
fragment: “You brought only one candle into the room?”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first‑person narrator ("I") — the same person who answered the preceding questions about the candle and the grease.
- Who is addressed: The person who asked "You brought only one candle into the room?" (an interrogator/observer present in the scene — likely the investigator or another participant in the conversation).
- Topic: That Lawrence Cavendish was carrying the sole candle; he became very upset and was visibly frozen (paralysed) because he saw something on the mantelpiece.
- Where they are: In the room already under discussion (the room with the writing‑table and mantelpiece — the scene of the earlier candle‑grease observation, i.e. Mrs. Inglethorp's room/sitting room).
fragment:
“Yes. Lawrence Cavendish was carrying it. But he was very upset. He
seemed to see something over here”—I indicated the mantelpiece—“that
absolutely paralysed him.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot (the detective).
- Who is being addressed: the narrator (Hastings) and the others present in the room (including Lawrence Cavendish and any investigators/household members).
- Topic: Poirot is commenting on a grease/soot mark on the wall and whether it could have come from the candle in the room — noting the mark is white grease while Lawrence’s candle (still on the dressing-table) is pink, and that Mrs. Inglethorp had only a reading lamp.
- Where they are: standing in Mrs. Inglethorp’s room (near the mantelpiece and dressing-table), examining the wall and discussing how the mark was made.
fragment:
“That is interesting,” said Poirot quickly. “Yes, it is suggestive”—his
eye sweeping the whole length of the wall—“but it was not his candle
that made this great patch, for you perceive that this is white grease;
whereas Monsieur Lawrence’s candle, which is still on the
dressing-table, is pink. On the other hand, Mrs. Inglethorp had no
candlestick in the room, only a reading-lamp.”

annotation:
Speaker: the narrator (Hastings) — "Then...what do you deduce?"  
Addressee: Hercule Poirot.  
Topic: Hastings asks Poirot to draw a conclusion from the physical evidence they have just been discussing — the large white grease patch on the wall above the mantelpiece, Lawrence Cavendish having brought a single pink candle and appearing paralysed by something he saw near the mantelpiece, and Mrs. Inglethorp's lack of a candlestick (she had only a reading lamp).  
Location: in Mrs. Inglethorp's room (near the mantelpiece and dressing-table), where they are inspecting the scene.
fragment: “Then,” I said, “what do you deduce?”

annotation:
Speaker identities: "I" is the narrator, Dr. John H. Watson. "My friend" refers to Hercule Poirot. The line is Watson reporting Poirot's response to him.

Addressee: Poirot is speaking to Watson (answering Watson's question, “Then, what do you deduce?”).

Topic: They are discussing the clues in the room — specifically the white grease patch on the wall/mantelpiece, the different candles (Lawrence Cavendish’s pink candle on the dressing‑table vs. the white grease), and what these facts imply about who was carrying an object and what paralysed Lawrence. Poirot's reply is to prompt Watson to make his own deductive inference rather than supplying it.

Location: They are in Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedroom/dressing‑room, standing by the mantelpiece and dressing‑table, examining the wall and the candle remnants. [[ ## completed ## ]]
fragment:
To which my friend only made a rather irritating reply, urging me to
use my own natural faculties.

annotation:
Speaker: "I" — the narrator (Dr. Watson–type companion, i.e., Captain Hastings) is speaking.
Addressee: Monsieur Hercule Poirot, the detective.
Topic: Hastings asks about the "sixth point" in Poirot's running list of clues/evidence and suggests that point refers to a small sample of cocoa (an item of physical evidence).
Location/context: They are in the room they are examining (by the dressing-table and the wall with the grease patch)—the scene of inquiry (Mrs. Inglethorp’s room/the victim's bedroom), discussing details like candles and a reading-lamp while Poirot enumerates his deductions.
fragment: “And the sixth point?” I asked. “I suppose it is the sample of cocoa.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot (the detective).
- Who is addressed: "I" — the narrator, Captain Hastings (Poirot's friend and companion).
- Topic: Poirot is answering Hastings' question about the "sixth point" in a list of deductions about the case; Hastings had guessed the sixth point might be the sample of cocoa, but Poirot declines to reveal it now (saying he may have thought of that but will keep it to himself).
- Where they are: Not specified in the fragment or prior lines; it is a private conversation between Poirot and Hastings during their investigation (commonly at Poirot's rooms or wherever they are discussing the case).
fragment:
“No,” said Poirot thoughtfully. “I might have included that in the six,
but I did not. No, the sixth point I will keep to myself for the
present.”

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot (the detective).  
Addressed to: the narrator, Captain Hastings (referred to as "my friend" earlier).  
Topic: Poirot is examining the room's fireplace; he is considering that the fire may have destroyed important evidence but wonders if something might have survived in the ashes.  
Location: in the room they are investigating (standing beside the grate/fireplace).
fragment:
He looked quickly round the room. “There is nothing more to be done
here, I think, unless”—he stared earnestly and long at the dead ashes
in the grate. “The fire burns—and it destroys. But by chance—there
might be—let us see!”

annotation:
- Who is acting/speaking: "He" is Hercule Poirot (the detective introduced in the prior lines).
- Who is addressed/nearby: The action is taking place before the narrator ("I" from the history), who has been questioning Poirot; others present are not named here.
- Topic: Poirot is carefully searching the ashes in the fireplace (sorting ashes into the fender) for a clue — related to the "sixth point" he mentioned earlier. His faint exclamation signals he has found something of significance.
- Where: At the scene by the fireplace (the grate and fender) in the room under investigation.
fragment:
Deftly, on hands and knees, he began to sort the ashes from the grate
into the fender, handling them with the greatest caution. Suddenly, he
gave a faint exclamation.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot.  
Addressed to: Captain Arthur Hastings.  
Topic: While examining the dead ashes in the fireplace (he has been sifting them on hands and knees), Poirot has found something that needs delicate handling and urgently asks Hastings to bring forceps so he can pick up the object as part of the investigation.  
Location: the room with the fireplace/grate (the scene of the inquiry, likely a sitting- or drawing-room).  
Tone: sudden, urgent exclamation.
fragment: “The forceps, Hastings!”

annotation:
Speaker: The detective who cried "The forceps, Hastings!" (Hercule Poirot). 
Addressee / narration: "I" is Captain Arthur Hastings, the narrator, who hands the forceps.
Topic: Using forceps to retrieve a small, half‑charred scrap of paper from the ashes — i.e., extracting possible evidence from the fireplace.
Where: In the same room by the grate/fireplace where they have been sorting the ashes (the scene of the investigation).
fragment:
I quickly handed them to him, and with skill he extracted a small piece
of half charred paper.

annotation:

- Who is addressed: He is speaking to Hastings (the companion who handed him the forceps); the narrator "I" is Dr. Watson, present at the scene. ("mon ami" = "my friend.")
- What is the topic: The small piece of half‑charred paper Holmes has just extracted from the ashes/grate — he is asking for their opinion of this clue.
- Where are they: Beside the fireplace (at the grate/fender) in the room where they are examining the ashes during the investigation.

annotation:

- Where they are: With Hercule Poirot at the place where the charred paper was found (the scene or an adjoining room where they inspected the burned remains).

fragment: [Illustration]

Suddenly an idea struck me.

fragment:
I relinquished the piece of paper, and watched him put it away in his
case, with the same methodical care that he bestowed on everything. My
brain was in a whirl. What was this complication of a will? Who had
destroyed it? The person who had left the candle grease on the floor?
Obviously. But how had anyone gained admission? All the doors had been
bolted on the inside.

annotation:

fragment:
“Now, my friend,” said Poirot briskly, “we will go. I should like to
ask a few questions of the parlourmaid—Dorcas, her name is, is it not?”

annotation:

We passed through Alfred Inglethorp’s room, and Poirot delayed long
enough to make a brief but fairly comprehensive examination of it. We
went out through that door, locking both it and that of Mrs.
Inglethorp’s room as before.

annotation:

I took him down to the boudoir which he had expressed a wish to see,
and went myself in search of Dorcas.

lost in admiration, before the various shaped flower beds.

“Admirable!” he murmured. “Admirable! What symmetry! Observe that
crescent; and those diamonds—their neatness rejoices the eye. The
spacing of the plants, also, is perfect. It has been recently done; is

Contextual tone: resigned acceptance — the narrator shrugs, signaling he won't press the argument.

I shrugged my shoulders. There was really no arguing with him if he
chose to take that line.

and her grey hair rose in stiff waves under her white cap. She was the
very model and picture of a good old-fashioned servant.

- Topic: the servant describes overhearing a violent domestic quarrel between the mistress of the house and Mr. Inglethorp. The mistress accuses him of lying and deceiving her, of repaying her ill for having supported him, and says she will act despite any fear of publicity or scandal; the servant did not catch Mr. Inglethorp’s replies and left when they appeared to be coming out.
- Where: the servant was in the hall outside the room where the argument took place; the voices came from inside a closed room in the house. The time was roughly around four o’clock in the afternoon.
fragment:
“I couldn’t say exactly, sir, but it wasn’t tea-time by a long way.
Perhaps four o’clock—or it may have been a bit later. Well, sir, as I
said, I happened to be passing along, when I heard voices very loud and
angry in here. I didn’t exactly mean to listen, but—well, there it is.
I stopped. The door was shut, but the mistress was speaking very sharp
and clear, and I heard what she said quite plainly. ‘You have lied to
me, and deceived me,’ she said. I didn’t hear what Mr. Inglethorp
replied. He spoke a good bit lower than she did—but she answered: ‘How
dare you? I have kept you and clothed you and fed you! You owe
everything to me! And this is how you repay me! By bringing disgrace
upon our name!’ Again I didn’t hear what he said, but she went on:
‘Nothing that you can say will make any difference. I see my duty
clearly. My mind is made up. You need not think that any fear of
publicity, or scandal between husband and wife will deter me.’ Then I
thought I heard them coming out, so I went off quickly.”

annotation:

Everyone was assembled in the dining-room. Under the circumstances, we
were naturally not a cheerful party. The reaction after a shock is
always trying, and I think we were all suffering from it. Decorum and
good breeding naturally enjoined that our demeanour should be much as
usual, yet I could not help wondering if this self-control were really
a matter of great difficulty. There were no red eyes, no signs of
secretly indulged grief. I felt that I was right in my opinion that
Dorcas was the person most affected by the personal side of the

I pass over Alfred Inglethorp, who acted the bereaved widower in a
manner that I felt to be disgusting in its hypocrisy. Did he know that
we suspected him, I wondered. Surely he could not be unaware of the
fact, conceal it as we would. Did he feel some secret stirring of fear,
or was he confident that his crime would go unpunished? Surely the
suspicion in the atmosphere must warn him that he was already a marked
man.

It occurred to me that he might have been making inquiries at Raikes’s
farm; so, finding him out when I called at Leastways Cottage on
Wednesday evening, I walked over there by the fields, hoping to meet
him. But there was no sign of him, and I hesitated to go right up to

me cunningly.

is retarded under certain conditions, none of which, however, appear to
have been present in this case. I presume Mrs. Inglethorp took the
coffee after dinner about eight o’clock, whereas the symptoms did not
manifest themselves until the early hours of the morning, which, on the
face of it, points to the drug having been taken much later in the
evening.”

I stared at the two men intently. There was certainly nothing of the
policeman about them. I should never have suspected them of being
official personages.

annotation:

The topic is the legal finding as to the cause of death: the jury returns a verdict of "wilful murder" but cannot name the culprit ("some person or persons unknown"). The setting is the inquest hearing (a coroner's court) where the verdict is being read.

fragment:
CHAPTER VII.
POIROT PAYS HIS DEBTS

As we came out of the Stylites Arms, Poirot drew me aside by a gentle
pressure of the arm. I understood his object. He was waiting for the
Scotland Yard men.

accosted the shorter of the two.

- Notes: Japp’s “moosier” is his accented, jocular pronunciation of “monsieur.” The passage serves to establish that Japp and Poirot have a prior working relationship and to introduce Poirot to the other officer.
fragment:
“Why, if it isn’t Mr. Poirot!” cried the Inspector. He turned to the
other man. “You’ve heard me speak of Mr. Poirot? It was in 1904 he and
I worked together—the Abercrombie forgery case—you remember, he was run
down in Brussels. Ah, those were great days, moosier. Then, do you
remember ‘Baron’ Altara? There was a pretty rogue for you! He eluded
the clutches of half the police in Europe. But we nailed him in
Antwerp—thanks to Mr. Poirot here.”

annotation:

Summerhaye was still looking rather sceptical, but Japp continued his

annotation:
Speaker: Inspector Japp (a Scotland Yard detective).
Addressed to: Monsieur Hercule Poirot (and the others present, including Summerhaye).
Topic: Japp is explaining investigative procedure — that the police ("the Yard") have only seen the case "from the outside" and are at a disadvantage when they are not first on the scene. He acknowledges Poirot had the advantage of being on the spot early and may have picked up crucial hints. Japp states his conclusion that Mr. Inglethorp murdered his wife (based on the inquest evidence) and expresses surprise the jury did not return a verdict of "Wilful Murder," blaming the Coroner for holding the jury back. He also mentions that the Yard only got there quickly because a capable doctor tipped them off via the Coroner.
Where: In the immediate aftermath of the coroner's inquest / at the place where the investigators are gathered to discuss the inquest and the crime scene (i.e., the investigation location close to the coroner's proceedings).
fragment:
“It’s this way,” he said, “so far, we’ve only seen the case from the
outside. That’s where the Yard’s at a disadvantage in a case of this
kind, where the murder’s only out, so to speak, after the inquest. A
lot depends on being on the spot first thing, and that’s where Mr.
Poirot’s had the start of us. We shouldn’t have been here as soon as
this even, if it hadn’t been for the fact that there was a smart doctor
on the spot, who gave us the tip through the Coroner. But you’ve been
on the spot from the first, and you may have picked up some little
hints. From the evidence at the inquest, Mr. Inglethorp murdered his
wife as sure as I stand here, and if anyone but you hinted the contrary
I’d laugh in his face. I must say I was surprised the jury didn’t bring
it in Wilful Murder against him right off. I think they would have, if
it hadn’t been for the Coroner—he seemed to be holding them back.”

annotation:

Addressee: Inspector James Japp (and bystanders including Superintendent Summerhaye).
Topic: Poirot is suggesting that Japp might already have an arrest warrant for Mr. Inglethorp, the man the inquest evidence points to as the murderer.
Where: In or immediately after the coroner’s inquest/coroner’s court, during the discussion following the inquest (the same scene Japp was speaking in).

now,” suggested Poirot.

The topic is the possible arrest/warrant and the murder inquiry. They are at the scene of the inquest / coroner's business (the inquest venue or its immediate surroundings), where the coroner, jury and police have been involved.

are both clean-shaven men. To make up successfully as one of these two

initial facial resemblance. But in the case of Alfred Inglethorp, all

eyes—those are the salient points about his personal appearance. Now,
what is the first instinct of the criminal? To divert suspicion from

follow him upstairs. There he caught me by the arm, and drew me aside.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot.
- Who is addressed: "me" — the narrator (Captain Hastings), whom Poirot had just drawn aside.
- What is the topic: Poirot is giving Hastings a quick instruction — to go to the other wing of the house and stand just by the baize door, remaining there without moving until Poirot returns (i.e., to wait/watch as part of the investigation).
- Where they are: upstairs in the house, in the corridor near the baize door that leads into the other wing; after speaking, Poirot rejoins the two detectives (Inspector Japp and the other detective present).
fragment:
“Quick, go to the other wing. Stand there—just this side of the baize
door. Do not move till I come.” Then, turning rapidly, he rejoined the
two detectives.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator (Captain Hastings) — this is first-person narration describing his own actions and thoughts.
- Who is addressed / who gave the instruction: Hercule Poirot gave the instruction ("Quick, go to the other wing..."). Other characters present nearby are Inspector Japp and "John," who went with Poirot to inspect rooms and speak to servants.
- Topic: Hastings was told to take up a post by the baize door to keep watch — presumably to observe or report anyone coming or going (or to guard access to a particular wing/room, likely Cynthia Murdoch’s). The fragment records Hastings waiting and wondering about the purpose of the post.
- Where they are: In the other wing of the house, standing just inside the corridor by the baize door (a cloth-covered dividing door) near the left wing where, except for Cynthia Murdoch’s room, the other bedrooms are located.
fragment:
I followed his instructions, taking up my position by the baize door,
and wondering what on earth lay behind the request. Why was I to stand
in this particular spot on guard? I looked thoughtfully down the
corridor in front of me. An idea struck me. With the exception of
Cynthia Murdoch’s, everyone’s room was in this left wing. Had that
anything to do with it? Was I to report who came or went? I stood
faithfully at my post. The minutes passed. Nobody came. Nothing
happened.

annotation:

Topic: he is reporting that he stood on guard as instructed and that about twenty minutes passed before Hercule Poirot returned to him.  
Where: upstairs in the hotel/boarding-house corridor, standing just inside the baize door in the left wing (near the other guests' rooms).  
Who is Poirot: Hercule Poirot, the Belgian detective who had sent Hastings to that post and later rejoined him.

fragment: “You have not stirred?”

console him.

excited you. I can tell you, that was a surprise to us all. There must
be more in this affair of Inglethorp’s with Mrs. Raikes than we
thought, to make him hold his tongue so persistently. What are you

described the doctor’s adventure. “He looked a regular scarecrow!
Plastered with mud from head to foot.”

we were racing down the park and along the high road to Tadminster.

annotation:

He explains that Mr. Inglethorp is now "out of it" (i.e., no longer a suspect or otherwise removed from consideration), that previously planted/manufactured clues have been discounted, and that they must now focus on who actually handled the coffee (which Mr. Inglethorp said he put down in the hall) or who passed through the hall while it stood there. He points out that, based on the narrator's account, only Mrs. Cavendish and Mademoiselle Cynthia can be positively excluded from having gone near the coffee.

Where they are: In the car en route to Tadminster (they had just left and were "racing down the park and along the high road to Tadminster").

Contextual notes: Poirot refers to evidence discussed at the inquest and to the need to discover the real (non-manufactured) clues and the person who either delivered the coffee to Mrs. Inglethorp or crossed the hall while the coffee stood there. ([[ ## completed ## ]])
fragment:
“Well, _mon ami_, a good deal you can guess for yourself. Of course you
realize that, now Mr. Inglethorp is out of it, the whole position is
greatly changed. We are face to face with an entirely new problem. We
know now that there is one person who did not buy the poison. We have
cleared away the manufactured clues. Now for the real ones. I have
ascertained that anyone in the household, with the exception of Mrs.
Cavendish, who was playing tennis with you, could have personated Mr.
Inglethorp on Monday evening. In the same way, we have his statement
that he put the coffee down in the hall. No one took much notice of
that at the inquest—but now it has a very different significance. We
must find out who did take that coffee to Mrs. Inglethorp eventually,
or who passed through the hall whilst it was standing there. From your
account, there are only two people whom we can positively say did not
go near the coffee—Mrs. Cavendish, and Mademoiselle Cynthia.”

fragment:

Mary Cavendish could certainly not rest under suspicion.

fragment:
This proceeding of Poirot’s, in respect of the cocoa, puzzled me
intensely. I could see neither rhyme nor reason in it. However, my
confidence in him, which at one time had rather waned, was fully
restored since his belief in Alfred Inglethorp’s innocence had been so
triumphantly vindicated.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The passage is narrated by "I" — Captain Arthur Hastings, Poirot’s friend and the story’s first-person narrator.

fragment:
The funeral of Mrs. Inglethorp took place the following day, and on
Monday, as I came down to a late breakfast, John drew me aside, and
informed me that Mr. Inglethorp was leaving that morning, to take up
his quarters at the Stylites Arms until he should have completed his
plans.

annotation:
Speaker: John Cavendish (referred to by the narrator as "my honest friend").
Addressed to: Captain Arthur Hastings (the narrator) — he calls him "Hastings."
Topic: John's relief that Mr. Alfred Inglethorp is leaving Styles (he's taking rooms at the Stylites Arms). He admits the household behaved badly in suspecting Inglethorp of wrongdoing, feels awkward guilt about it but still doesn't like him, and is glad Inglethorp won't be staying at or "lording it" over the estate. ("The mater" = the late lady of the house; "Styles" = the family estate; "Stylites Arms" = an inn where Inglethorp will stay.)
Where: At Styles, during a late breakfast in the house — John had just drawn Hastings aside at breakfast to tell him this.
fragment:
“And really it’s a great relief to think he’s going, Hastings,”
continued my honest friend. “It was bad enough before, when we thought
he’d done it, but I’m hanged if it isn’t worse now, when we all feel
guilty for having been so down on the fellow. The fact is, we’ve
treated him abominably. Of course, things did look black against him. I
don’t see how anyone could blame us for jumping to the conclusions we
did. Still, there it is, we were in the wrong, and now there’s a
beastly feeling that one ought to make amends; which is difficult, when
one doesn’t like the fellow a bit better than one did before. The whole
thing’s damned awkward! And I’m thankful he’s had the tact to take
himself off. It’s a good thing Styles wasn’t the mater’s to leave to
him. Couldn’t bear to think of the fellow lording it here. He’s welcome
to her money.”

annotation: Spoken by the narrator, Captain Arthur Hastings. He is addressing John (John Cavendish), who has just told him that Alfred Inglethorp is leaving. The topic is whether John will be able to keep up/maintain Styles (the family house) after Inglethorp goes — i.e., managing the household/finances. They are at Styles, coming down to a late breakfast in the house.
fragment: “You’ll be able to keep up the place all right?” I asked.

annotation:

Addressee: The narrator, Arthur Hastings (the "me" who asked the question).
Topic: Whether the family can "keep up the place" (maintain the Styles estate) after Mrs. Inglethorp’s death. John says half the late lady’s money is tied to the estate, that "death duties" (inheritance taxes) apply, that Lawrence (a relative who will remain with them) contributes his share, and that although John is personally short of cash he expects creditors ("the Johnnies") to wait.
Where: At Styles, during late breakfast in the house — John had drawn Hastings aside at the breakfast table.
fragment:
“Oh, yes. There are the death duties, of course, but half my father’s
money goes with the place, and Lawrence will stay with us for the
present, so there is his share as well. We shall be pinched at first,
of course, because, as I once told you, I am in a bit of a hole
financially myself. Still, the Johnnies will wait now.”

annotation:

fragment:
In the general relief at Inglethorp’s approaching departure, we had the
most genial breakfast we had experienced since the tragedy. Cynthia,
whose young spirits were naturally buoyant, was looking quite her
pretty self again, and we all, with the exception of Lawrence, who
seemed unalterably gloomy and nervous, were quietly cheerful, at the
opening of a new and hopeful future.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first‑person narrator of the scene (a member of the Styles household — the same narrator who spoke in the earlier lines).
- Who is addressed: This is narrative commentary directed to the reader (not a line of dialogue to another character).
- What is the topic: The national newspapers’ sensational coverage of the household tragedy (headlines, biographies, innuendo), treating the case as a public scandal dubbed “The Mysterious Affair at Styles.” The papers pounced especially because the war was momentarily quiet.
- Where they are: At Styles, the country house — during the household’s breakfast after Inglethorp’s death/tragedy (the domestic setting already established in the preceding history).
fragment:
The papers, of course, had been full of the tragedy. Glaring headlines,
sandwiched biographies of every member of the household, subtle
innuendoes, the usual familiar tag about the police having a clue.
Nothing was spared us. It was a slack time. The war was momentarily
inactive, and the newspapers seized with avidity on this crime in
fashionable life: “The Mysterious Affair at Styles” was the topic of
the moment.

fragment:
Naturally it was very annoying for the Cavendishes. The house was
constantly besieged by reporters, who were consistently denied
admission, but who continued to haunt the village and the grounds,
where they lay in wait with cameras, for any unwary members of the
household. We all lived in a blast of publicity. The Scotland Yard men
came and went, examining, questioning, lynx-eyed and reserved of
tongue. Towards what end they were working, we did not know. Had they
any clue, or would the whole thing remain in the category of
undiscovered crimes?

After breakfast, Dorcas came up to me rather mysteriously, and asked if
she might have a few words with me.

“Well, it’s just this, sir. You’ll be seeing the Belgian gentleman
to-day perhaps?” I nodded. “Well, sir, you know how he asked me so
particular if the mistress, or anyone else, had a green dress?”

“No, not that, sir. But since then I’ve remembered what the young
gentlemen”—John and Lawrence were still the “young gentlemen” to
Dorcas—“call the ‘dressing-up box.’ It’s up in the front attic, sir. A
great chest, full of old clothes and fancy dresses, and what not. And
it came to me sudden like that there might be a green dress amongst
them. So, if you’d tell the Belgian gentleman——”

“Thank you very much, sir. A very nice gentleman he is, sir. And quite
a different class from them two detectives from London, what goes
prying about, and asking questions. I don’t hold with foreigners as a
rule, but from what the newspapers say I make out as how these brave
Belges isn’t the ordinary run of foreigners, and certainly he’s a most
polite spoken gentleman.”

Dear old Dorcas! As she stood there, with her honest face upturned to
mine, I thought what a fine specimen she was of the old-fashioned
servant that is so fast dying out.

I thought I might as well go down to the village at once, and look up
Poirot; but I met him half-way, coming up to the house, and at once
gave him Dorcas’s message.

We entered the house by one of the windows. There was no one in the
hall, and we went straight up to the attic.

Sure enough, there was the chest, a fine old piece, all studded with

garment.

fragment:
Poirot bundled everything out on the floor with scant ceremony. There
were one or two green fabrics of varying shades; but Poirot shook his
head over them all. He seemed somewhat apathetic in the search, as
though he expected no great results from it. Suddenly he gave an
exclamation.

examining it closely. “New,” he remarked. “Yes, quite new.”

the other things on top of it as before, and made his way briskly
downstairs. He went straight to the pantry, where we found Dorcas
busily polishing her silver.

fragment:
“Well, sir, not very often nowadays, though from time to time we do
have what the young gentlemen call ‘a dress-up night.’ And very funny
it is sometimes, sir. Mr. Lawrence, he’s wonderful. Most comic! I shall
never forget the night he came down as the Char of Persia, I think he
called it—a sort of Eastern King it was. He had the big paper knife in
his hand, and ‘Mind, Dorcas,’ he says, ‘you’ll have to be very
respectful. This is my specially sharpened scimitar, and it’s off with
your head if I’m at all displeased with you!’ Miss Cynthia, she was
what they call an Apache, or some such name—a Frenchified sort of
cut-throat, I take it to be. A real sight she looked. You’d never have
believed a pretty young lady like that could have made herself into
such a ruffian. Nobody would have known her.”

it, for he borrowed two skeins of my black wool to make it with! And

there was a beard up there at all. It must have been got quite lately,

Sir Ernest Heavywether’s speech in opening the case for the defence was
not a long one, but it was backed by the full force of his emphatic
manner. Never, he said, in the course of his long experience, had he
known a charge of murder rest on slighter evidence. Not only was it
entirely circumstantial, but the greater part of it was practically
unproved. Let them take the testimony they had heard and sift it
impartially. The strychnine had been found in a drawer in the
prisoner’s room. That drawer was an unlocked one, as he had pointed
out, and he submitted that there was no evidence to prove that it was
the prisoner who had concealed the poison there. It was, in fact, a
wicked and malicious attempt on the part of some third person to fix
the crime on the prisoner. The prosecution had been unable to produce a
shred of evidence in support of their contention that it was the
prisoner who ordered the black beard from Parkson’s. The quarrel which
had taken place between prisoner and his stepmother was freely
admitted, but both it and his financial embarrassments had been grossly
exaggerated.

But I stopped suddenly. For Poirot, uttering a hoarse and inarticulate
cry, again annihilated his masterpiece of cards, and putting his hands
over his eyes swayed backwards and forwards, apparently suffering the
keenest agony.

Addressee: Hercule Poirot.

Where: In the room where the company has just been assembled in the Cavendish house (the drawing/sitting room), while Poirot addresses the assembled guests.
fragment:
“_Messieurs, mesdames_, as you all know, I was called in by Monsieur
John Cavendish to investigate this case. I at once examined the bedroom
of the deceased which, by the advice of the doctors, had been kept
locked, and was consequently exactly as it had been when the tragedy
occurred. I found: first, a fragment of green material; second, a stain
on the carpet near the window, still damp; thirdly, an empty box of
bromide powders.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot (the detective).  
Addressee: The assembled company of household members and guests present in the room (the people Poirot bowed to — e.g., Miss Howard, Alfred Inglethorp, etc.).

Where: Poirot is recounting his examination of the deceased's bedroom (kept locked) and now speaking to everyone in the sitting/drawing-room where the company has assembled.

bolt of the communicating door between that room and the adjoining one
occupied by Mademoiselle Cynthia. I handed the fragment over to the
police who did not consider it of much importance. Nor did they
recognize it for what it was—a piece torn from a green land armlet.”

annotation:

Who is addressed: Hercule Poirot has been speaking to "Messieurs, mesdames" — the assembled company (family, guests and others present).

Cavendish. Therefore it must have been Mrs. Cavendish who entered the

fragment: “But that door was bolted on the inside!” I cried.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot (the detective) — he is answering Hastings’s exclamation.

Addressee: Capt. Arthur Hastings (the narrator) and the other listeners present (police at the house).

Topic: Poirot is explaining his reasoning and the tests that show Mrs. Cavendish lied about being in her own room. Location/context: At Styles (the country house where the murder occurred). Poirot refers to events at the inquest and to his subsequent investigations carried out in the house (the deceased’s room and Mrs. Cavendish’s room), and is speaking in the house in the presence of Hastings and the police.
fragment:
“When I examined the room, yes. But in the first place we have only her
word for it, since it was she who tried that particular door and
reported it fastened. In the ensuing confusion she would have had ample
opportunity to shoot the bolt across. I took an early opportunity of
verifying my conjectures. To begin with, the fragment corresponds
exactly with a tear in Mrs. Cavendish’s armlet. Also, at the inquest,
Mrs. Cavendish declared that she had heard, from her own room, the fall
of the table by the bed. I took an early opportunity of testing that
statement by stationing my friend Monsieur Hastings in the left wing of
the building, just outside Mrs. Cavendish’s door. I myself, in company
with the police, went to the deceased’s room, and whilst there I,
apparently accidentally, knocked over the table in question, but found
that, as I had expected, Monsieur Hastings had heard no sound at all.
This confirmed my belief that Mrs. Cavendish was not speaking the truth
when she declared that she had been dressing in her room at the time of
the tragedy. In fact, I was convinced that, far from having been in her
own room, Mrs. Cavendish was actually in the deceased’s room when the
alarm was given.”

Where: At Styles (the main room where Poirot, Hastings, police and the household are gathered while Poirot recounts his findings).

- Where they are: In the Cavendish house, during a formal explanation to the family/household (the detective is addressing those gathered in the house, likely in a drawing‑room or similar sitting room).
fragment:
“I proceeded to reason on that assumption. Mrs. Cavendish is in her
mother-in-law’s room. We will say that she is seeking for something and
has not yet found it. Suddenly Mrs. Inglethorp awakens and is seized
with an alarming paroxysm. She flings out her arm, overturning the bed
table, and then pulls desperately at the bell. Mrs. Cavendish,
startled, drops her candle, scattering the grease on the carpet. She
picks it up, and retreats quickly to Mademoiselle Cynthia’s room,
closing the door behind her. She hurries out into the passage, for the
servants must not find her where she is. But it is too late! Already
footsteps are echoing along the gallery which connects the two wings.
What can she do? Quick as thought, she hurries back to the young girl’s
room, and starts shaking her awake. The hastily aroused household come
trooping down the passage. They are all busily battering at Mrs.
Inglethorp’s door. It occurs to nobody that Mrs. Cavendish has not
arrived with the rest, but—and this is significant—I can find no one
who saw her come from the other wing.” He looked at Mary Cavendish. “Am
I right, madame?”

- Who is addressed: Mary Cavendish (Mrs. Cavendish) — the woman Holmes has been accusing of having been in the deceased’s room and of not telling the truth.
- What is the topic: Holmes’s accusation/reconstruction that Mrs. Cavendish was in the dead woman’s room at the time of the alarm, dropped a candle, retreated, and lied about where she was; he has asked her to confirm or deny it.
- Where they are: in the house where the investigation/inquest and the questioning are taking place — the room where the household (Holmes, the police, the narrator, and others) are gathered and where Holmes has confronted Mary.
- Note on the fragment: “She bowed her head.” refers to Mary Cavendish’s silent, nonverbal reaction to Holmes’s question (a sign of acknowledgment, shame, or refusal to speak).

fragment:
“The temperature on that day, messieurs, was 80 degrees in the shade.
Yet Mrs. Inglethorp ordered a fire! Why? Because she wished to destroy
something, and could think of no other way. You will remember that, in
consequence of the War economics practiced at Styles, no waste paper
was thrown away. There was therefore no means of destroying a thick
document such as a will. The moment I heard of a fire being lighted in
Mrs. Inglethorp’s room, I leaped to the conclusion that it was to
destroy some important document—possibly a will. So the discovery of
the charred fragment in the grate was no surprise to me. I did not, of
course, know at the time that the will in question had only been made
this afternoon, and I will admit that, when I learnt that fact, I fell
into a grievous error. I came to the conclusion that Mrs. Inglethorp’s
determination to destroy her will arose as a direct consequence of the
quarrel she had that afternoon, and that therefore the quarrel took
place after, and not before the making of the will.

He explains that Mrs. Emily Inglethorp’s two similar remarks, once at about 4 p.m. and again at about 5 p.m., were made in different mental states (4 p.m.: angry and controlled; 5 p.m.: distressed and shocked). From this he infers that something happened between those times which altered the meaning and addressee of her words (he now thinks the earlier remark was aimed at John Cavendish).

Context note: Earlier Poirot admitted he had erred about the sequence of events (his previous theory tied the will and the quarrel to a different time); here he sets out the corrected interpretation based on Dorcas’s testimony.

addressed, not to her husband, but to Mr. John Cavendish. At five
o’clock, an hour later, she uses almost the same words, but the

“Let us reconstruct. At four o’clock, Mrs. Inglethorp quarrels with her
son, and threatens to denounce him to his wife—who, by the way,
overheard the greater part of the conversation. At four-thirty, Mrs.
Inglethorp, in consequence of a conversation on the validity of wills,
makes a will in favour of her husband, which the two gardeners witness.
At five o’clock, Dorcas finds her mistress in a state of considerable
agitation, with a slip of paper—‘a letter,’ Dorcas thinks—in her hand,
and it is then that she orders the fire in her room to be lighted.
Presumably, then, between four-thirty and five o’clock, something has
occurred to occasion a complete revolution of feeling, since she is now
as anxious to destroy the will, as she was before to make it. What was
that something?

“One can only guess, but I believe my guess to be correct. Mrs.
Inglethorp had no stamps in her desk. We know this, because later she
asked Dorcas to bring her some. Now in the opposite corner of the room
stood her husband’s desk—locked. She was anxious to find some stamps,
and, according to my theory, she tried her own keys in the desk. That
one of them fitted I know. She therefore opened the desk, and in
searching for the stamps she came across something else—that slip of
paper which Dorcas saw in her hand, and which assuredly was never meant
for Mrs. Inglethorp’s eyes. On the other hand, Mrs. Cavendish believed
that the slip of paper to which her mother-in-law clung so tenaciously
was a written proof of her own husband’s infidelity. She demanded it
from Mrs. Inglethorp who assured her, quite truly, that it had nothing
to do with that matter. Mrs. Cavendish did not believe her. She thought
that Mrs. Inglethorp was shielding her stepson. Now Mrs. Cavendish is a
very resolute woman, and, behind her mask of reserve, she was madly
jealous of her husband. She determined to get hold of that paper at all
costs, and in this resolution chance came to her aid. She happened to
pick up the key of Mrs. Inglethorp’s despatch-case, which had been lost
that morning. She knew that her mother-in-law invariably kept all
important papers in this particular case.
