Poirot, eh? But you would not trust me.”

annotation:
- Speaker: Lawrence (a character present in the scene).
- Addressed to: Hercule Poirot (Monsieur Poirot) and the others present, including Mary.
- Topic: Lawrence is stating his realization about the cause of a delayed toxic reaction — that the victim was given a sedative in cocoa followed later by poisoned coffee, which explains why the fatal effects were delayed.
- Where/setting: The conversation is taking place in the same room where Poirot has been questioning and revealing things to Mary and the group (an investigative setting in the house, immediately following Poirot's remarks).
fragment:
“I see everything now,” said Lawrence. “The drugged cocoa, taken on top
of the poisoned coffee, amply accounts for the delay.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot.
- Who is addressed: Lawrence and the others present in the room (the people Poirot has been questioning).
- What is the topic: Whether the coffee was poisoned — Poirot points out a difficulty because Mrs. Inglethorp never drank the coffee, which undermines the explanation involving poisoned coffee and drugged cocoa.
- Where they are: In Mrs. Inglethorp’s house, during Poirot’s post-murder questioning of the household.
fragment:
“Exactly. But was the coffee poisoned, or was it not? We come to a
little difficulty here, since Mrs. Inglethorp never drank it.”

annotation: The one-word cry “What?” is shouted by everyone present — the assembled company listening to the exchange (including Hercule Poirot and Lawrence and the unnamed speaker who referred to “Papa Poirot”). It is directed at the two men who have just been reconstructing the poisoning (Lawrence’s explanation about the drugged cocoa and the preceding poisoned coffee, and the reply questioning whether the coffee was actually poisoned). The topic is astonishment at this new reconstruction of how the victim was drugged/poisoned and at Poirot’s immediate objection that Mrs. Inglethorp never drank the coffee (a difficulty for the poisoning theory). The scene takes place where the household has gathered to hear the inquiry — in the Inglethorp house, in the room where the group is discussing the case.
fragment: “What?” The cry of surprise was universal.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The same person who spoke in the previous line ("Exactly") — i.e., the investigator/detective who is leading the explanation.
- Who is addressed: The assembled company present (including Lawrence and the others who cried out in surprise).
- What is the topic: He is explaining the stain on the carpet in Mrs. Inglethorp’s room — arguing that a treacherous, tilting table had caused Mrs. Inglethorp’s cup to be deposited on the floor, leaving a damp coffee-smell stain and china splinters. This explanation shows the cup spilled (so she did not drink the coffee), and the speaker demonstrates the effect by placing his own case on the table and watching it fall onto the same spot.
- Where they are: They are discussing the case in Mrs. Inglethorp’s house; the evidence being described (the stain) is in Mrs. Inglethorp’s room.
fragment:
“No. You will remember my speaking of a stain on the carpet in Mrs.
Inglethorp’s room? There were some peculiar points about that stain. It
was still damp, it exhaled a strong odour of coffee, and imbedded in
the nap of the carpet I found some little splinters of china. What had
happened was plain to me, for not two minutes before I had placed my
little case on the table near the window, and the table, tilting up,
had deposited it upon the floor on precisely the identical spot. In
exactly the same way, Mrs. Inglethorp had laid down her cup of coffee
on reaching her room the night before, and the treacherous table had
played her the same trick.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot, the detective.
- Who is addressed: the assembled people in the room — the other investigators/witnesses present (the group whose earlier surprised cry is mentioned).
- What is the topic: Poirot is reconstructing how the poison (strychnine) was administered — explaining that coffee and cocoa were not the carriers and proposing that Mrs. Inglethorp’s medicine was the “third medium” used to disguise the poison, placed between seven and nine o’clock.
- Where they are: in the room where the inquiry is taking place, discussing evidence from Mrs. Inglethorp’s room (the stain on the carpet and the bedside table); Poirot looks round the same room as he speaks.
fragment:
“What happened next is mere guess work on my part, but I should say
that Mrs. Inglethorp picked up the broken cup and placed it on the
table by the bed. Feeling in need of a stimulant of some kind, she
heated up her cocoa, and drank it off then and there. Now we are faced
with a new problem. We know the cocoa contained no strychnine. The
coffee was never drunk. Yet the strychnine must have been administered
between seven and nine o’clock that evening. What third medium was
there—a medium so suitable for disguising the taste of strychnine that
it is extraordinary no one has thought of it?” Poirot looked round the
room, and then answered himself impressively. “Her medicine!”

annotation:
Speaker: "I" is the story's first-person narrator (Captain Hastings).  
Addressed to: Hercule Poirot.  
Topic: A question confirming Poirot's suggestion that the murderer put strychnine into Mrs. Inglethorp's medicine/tonic.  
Where: In Mrs. Inglethorp's room, while the characters are examining the scene (near the bed and the table where the cup and tonic were placed). The line responds directly to Poirot's exclamation "Her medicine!" and follows the preceding discussion about the coffee, cocoa and the timing of the poisoning.
fragment:
“Do you mean that the murderer introduced the strychnine into her
tonic?” I cried.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot.  
Addressees: The narrator (Captain Hastings — "I cried") and others present in the room (the investigating party).  
Topic: Poirot is explaining that the fatal dose of strychnine was already present in Mrs. Inglethorp’s prescribed medicine (the tonic from Dr. Wilkins) and will read an extract from a dispensing manual found in the Red Cross Hospital dispensary at Tadminster to support this.  
Location: In Mrs. Inglethorp’s room (the scene of the inquiry), during the investigation of her poisoning.
fragment:
“There was no need to introduce it. It was already there—in the
mixture. The strychnine that killed Mrs. Inglethorp was the identical
strychnine prescribed by Dr. Wilkins. To make that clear to you, I will
read you an extract from a book on dispensing which I found in the
Dispensary of the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster:

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot, reading aloud from the dispensing textbook he found.
Addressee: The narrator (Captain Hastings) and the others present in the room — the assembled investigators.
Topic: An extract from a dispensing/dispensing textbook that begins with a “famous” prescription; Poirot is using it to show that the strychnine that killed Mrs. Inglethorp was already present in the medicine prescribed by Dr. Wilkins, not introduced later into the cocoa or coffee.
Location: In Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedroom (the scene of the death) where Poirot has been examining the room; he earlier said he found the book in the Dispensary of the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster.
fragment: “‘The following prescription has become famous in text books:

annotation:
Speaker: the person who replied in the previous line (“There was no need…”) — the investigator/explainer in the scene — is reading aloud.

Addressee: the narrator (the one who cried out) and anyone else present; the excerpt is being read to them to prove a point about the poisoning.

Topic: an extract from a dispensing (pharmacy) book — a prescription entry listing "Strychninae Sulph." (sulphate of strychnine) with the dose "1 gr." (one grain). This shows the exact strychnine formulation/dose prescribed and supports the claim that the poison was already present in the mixture.

Where: the extract was taken from a book found in the Dispensary of the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster; the reading is happening where the investigator and narrator are discussing the case.

(Additional note: "1 gr." means one grain, an old unit of mass — about 65 mg.)
fragment: Strychninae Sulph. . . . . . 1 gr.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator (an investigator/observer) who said he had found a dispensing manual and is reading aloud from it.
- Who is addressed: The assembled listeners (other characters present—an audience, investigators or persons at the inquiry); the narrator says "I will read you..." so he is reading to them.
- What is the topic: A quoted, "famous" prescription from a dispensing textbook intended to show the exact formulation (including the strychnine) that matches the poison which killed Mrs. Inglethorp. The fragment is simply the next line of that prescription: Potassium bromide with its quantity.
- Where: The extract comes from a book the narrator found in the Dispensary of the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster; he is reading that extract aloud to the present listeners. 
(Note: the fragment continues the prescription list—it is not a new statement by a character.)
fragment: Potass Bromide . . . . . . . 3vi

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator/author of the passage (introducing a quotation).
- Who is addressed: The reader (particularly readers of medical textbooks or students).
- What is the topic: A quoted medical prescription. The lines list ingredients and amounts: Strychninae Sulph. (strychnine sulfate) 1 grain; Potass. Bromide (potassium bromide) in the amount shown; "Aqua ad. 3viii" means "add water up to a total volume of 3viii" — standard apothecaries' notation to make up the solution.
- Where they are: In a medical text or textbook (the narrator is quoting a prescription that "has become famous in text books").
fragment: Aqua ad. . . . . . . . . . . . . 3viii

annotation:
Speaker: the prescriber (physician or prescription writer).
Addressee: the apothecary/pharmacist who will compound the prescription.
Topic: an instruction to prepare a medicinal mixture — the preceding lines list ingredients (Strychninae sulph. 1 gr.; Potass. bromide, amount given; Aqua ad. indicating water to make up the volume). 
Meaning of fragment: "Fiat Mistura" is Latin for "Let a mixture be made" — a compounding order to make the mixture described.
Where: in a medical/dispensing context (doctor's prescription intended for the pharmacy or compounding room).
fragment: Fiat Mistura

annotation:
- Who is speaking: A medical author or apothecary/pharmacist (the writer of the prescription/formulary).
- Who is addressed: Other pharmacists, physicians, or readers of the medical recipe (practitioners following the mixture).
- What is the topic: A practical warning that when strychnine salts are mixed with a potassium-bromide solution the strychnine will precipitate as insoluble bromide crystals and collect on the bottom; this can concentrate the drug in the last doses and caused a fatality in one reported case (a lady in England who swallowed the precipitate in the final dose).
- Where they are / context: In a dispensary or within a printed/formular instruction (the prescription lines above are a compounding formula — "Potass. Bromide" and "Aqua" — and the note informs how the mixture behaves and its hazard).
fragment:
_This solution deposits in a few hours the greater part of the
strychnine salt as an insoluble bromide in transparent crystals. A lady
in England lost her life by taking a similar mixture: the precipitated
strychnine collected at the bottom, and in taking the last dose she
swallowed nearly all of it!_

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator/investigator (a detective-type narrator) is explaining the mechanics of the poisoning.  
- Who is addressed: The narrator is addressing a companion or the reader (implicitly “you” — likely Watson or a similar confidant).  
- What is the topic: How strychnine could be precipitated out of Mrs. Inglethorp’s medicine by adding bromide powder from an empty box, so that the toxic crystals settled as sediment and would be swallowed only in the final doses — i.e., an account of how the murder could have been effected and why the person who poured the medicine left the bottle unshaken.  
- Where they are / context: In the course of investigating Mrs. Inglethorp’s death (discussing evidence found at her house — the empty bromide powder box and the medicine bottle). The passage is an explanatory remark during that investigation.
fragment:
“Now there was, of course, no bromide in Dr. Wilkins’ prescription, but
you will remember that I mentioned an empty box of bromide powders. One
or two of those powders introduced into the full bottle of medicine
would effectually precipitate the strychnine, as the book describes,
and cause it to be taken in the last dose. You will learn later that
the person who usually poured out Mrs. Inglethorp’s medicine was always
extremely careful not to shake the bottle, but to leave the sediment at
the bottom of it undisturbed.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Sherlock Holmes (the detective, explaining his deductions).
- Who is addressed: Dr. Watson (the usual listener and narrator) and any others present (e.g., police or interested parties).
- What is the topic: Holmes is describing the murderer’s planned timing — cutting Mrs. Inglethorp’s bell wire and arranging for her to be alone so a poisoned dose would be fatal on Monday evening — and explaining that a last-minute delay in taking the medicine (and thus in the fatal dose) produced the physical evidence (the precipitated strychnine sediment) that Holmes now holds as the “final proof.”
- Where: The events described (cut bell wire, Mrs. Inglethorp left alone in the right wing) occurred at Mrs. Inglethorp’s house. The conversation itself is taking place where Holmes reports his conclusions (implied to be Holmes’s rooms or wherever he and Watson are discussing the case).
fragment:
“Throughout the case, there have been evidences that the tragedy was
intended to take place on Monday evening. On that day, Mrs.
Inglethorp’s bell wire was neatly cut, and on Monday evening
Mademoiselle Cynthia was spending the night with friends, so that Mrs.
Inglethorp would have been quite alone in the right wing, completely
shut off from help of any kind, and would have died, in all
probability, before medical aid could have been summoned. But in her
hurry to be in time for the village entertainment Mrs. Inglethorp
forgot to take her medicine, and the next day she lunched away from
home, so that the last—and fatal—dose was actually taken twenty-four
hours later than had been anticipated by the murderer; and it is owing
to that delay that the final proof—the last link of the chain—is now in
my hands.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Sherlock Holmes (the narrator has been recounting Holmes’s speech; "he" = Holmes).
- Who is addressed: the assembled listeners present with Holmes — chiefly Dr. Watson (the narrator) and the others in the room (family members and/or investigators gathered to hear Holmes’s explanation).
- What is the topic: Holmes is producing physical evidence — three thin strips of paper (the remnants/wrappers of bromide powders) that show how bromide was introduced into Mrs. Inglethorp’s medicine to precipitate strychnine and complete the murderer’s plan.
- Where they are: in the room where Holmes has been giving his account and revealing the final proof (the sitting/drawing-room where the case is being explained to those present).
fragment: Amid breathless excitement, he held out three thin strips of paper.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot (the detective — indicated by his French phrase "mes amis!").  
Addressed to: the assembled company present — family, friends and investigators (those listening breathlessly in the room).  
Topic: Poirot is producing three thin strips of paper that together form a letter written in the murderer's handwriting — a warning sent to Mrs. Inglethorp. He says the warning was ambiguous: it made her realize she was in danger but did not reveal the method (i.e., that the danger was poisoning of her medicine).  
Where: in the room at the Inglethorp house where the household and the investigators have gathered for Poirot’s explanation.
fragment:
“A letter in the murderer’s own hand-writing, _mes amis!_ Had it been a
little clearer in its terms, it is possible that Mrs. Inglethorp,
warned in time, would have escaped. As it was, she realized her danger,
but not the manner of it.”

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot (the detective).
Addressed to: the assembled listeners — Poirot’s colleagues and the household present (his friends and the investigators, e.g., Captain Hastings/Inspector Japp and the Inglethorp household members — "mes amis").
Topic: Poirot is reconstructing and about to read three thin strips of paper that form a torn letter written by the murderer; the letter is the final piece of evidence proving the murderer’s plan and the intended timing/method of Mrs. Inglethorp’s death.
Where: in the room where the case is being wound up — the gathering of suspects, witnesses and investigators in the Inglethorp house (the scene of the inquiry), in a tense, expectant silence.
fragment:
In the deathly silence, Poirot pieced together the slips of paper and,
clearing his throat, read:

annotation:
Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot is reading aloud — he has just pieced together three thin strips of paper and is declaiming the reconstructed text.

Who is addressed: The salutation "Dearest Evelyn:" is directed to Evelyn — the woman referred to earlier (Mrs. Inglethorp).

What is the topic: This is the opening line of a letter written by the murderer (described in the preceding lines as "a letter in the murderer’s own hand-writing"), a warning to Evelyn about a danger to her. Poirot is presenting the contents as evidence in the investigation.

Where they are: In a tense, silent room with Poirot and the assembled friends/investigators (he addresses them "mes amis"), gathered to hear the reconstructed letter read aloud as part of the murder inquiry.
fragment: ‘Dearest Evelyn:

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The passage is from a torn letter — the writer of the letter (who, as Poirot has just said, is the murderer) is the speaker in the fragment.
- Who is addressed: It is addressed to "Evelyn" — the recipient of the letter and presumably a co‑conspirator.
- What is the topic: The writer outlines a murder plot: they have postponed the deed to tonight, express confidence no one will suspect them, praise Evelyn’s idea about using "bromides" (sedative/chemical) as part of the scheme, and warn that they must be very careful.
- Where this is happening now: These lines are being read aloud by Hercule Poirot to the silent group after he pieced together the torn slips of the letter (i.e., in the room where the investigation/household members are gathered after Mrs. Inglethorp’s death). The "old woman" referred to is Mrs. Inglethorp, the victim.
fragment:
‘You will be anxious at hearing nothing. It is all right—only it
    will be to-night instead of last night. You understand. There’s a
    good time coming once the old woman is dead and out of the way. No
    one can possibly bring home the crime to me. That idea of yours
    about the bromides was a stroke of genius! But we must be very
    circumspect. A false step——’

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot, the detective, who has been reading aloud.
- Who is addressed: "My friends" — the assembled company in the room (family members, Dr. Hastings, Inspector Japp and other investigators/present parties).
- What is the topic: Poirot has just read fragments of an incriminating letter addressed to "Evelyn" that discusses arranging the old woman's death and mentions using bromides; he now notes the letter breaks off and asserts the writer's identity is obvious from the handwriting.
- Where they are: In the house where the murder is being investigated (the drawing-room/meeting room where the household and detectives are gathered).
fragment:
“Here, my friends, the letter breaks off. Doubtless the writer was
interrupted; but there can be no question as to his identity. We all
know this hand-writing and——”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Sherlock Holmes is reading aloud (or commenting) on the letter.
- Who is addressed: Holmes is speaking to his friends/present company — chiefly Dr. Watson and the others gathered with him.
- What is the topic: A fragment of a letter addressed "Dearest Evelyn" that reveals a plotful, conspiratorial plan — it speaks of an "old woman" being disposed of and mentions using "bromides"; Holmes is identifying the handwriting as belonging to someone everyone present knows.
- Where they are: In the room where the group is gathered (the sitting-room — Baker Street/Holmes's rooms), reacting to the troubling contents of the letter.

The howl in the fragment is a sudden, anguished cry from one of those present, reacting to the shocking identification and the murderous implication in the letter.
fragment: A howl that was almost a scream broke the silence.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: the person who earlier "howled" — an individual suddenly exposed and enraged (likely the person whose guilt is implicated by the letter).
- Who is addressed: the man who has just been reading and identifying the handwriting aloud (the speaker who said "Here, my friends... We all know this hand-writing").
- What is the topic: the incriminating letter that describes a planned murder (mentions bromides and the "old woman" being "out of the way") — the angry question asks how the reader came into possession of that letter.
- Where they are: in the same room where the letter is being read aloud to a group of people ("my friends"), i.e., an assembled company or inquest-type setting where the handwriting has just been identified.
fragment: “You devil! How did you get it?”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first line is spoken by the person reading a letter aloud to the company (in the novel this is the narrator reading to the assembled guests). The howl and the cry "You devil! How did you get it?" come from one of the listeners who suddenly recognizes the handwriting and reacts angrily.
- Who is addressed: "My friends" and the remarks are addressed to the assembled group of people in the room.
- What is the topic: The reader has produced a letter whose handwriting identifies its author; this revelation provokes a violent outburst from someone present.
- Where they are: In the room where the company is gathered (a drawing-room/parlour in the house). The fragment shows that, after the outburst, an enraged person attacks Hercule Poirot; Poirot dodges and the assailant falls.
fragment:
A chair was overturned. Poirot skipped nimbly aside. A quick movement
on his part, and his assailant fell with a crash.

annotation:

Addressee: The assembled people present in the room — "messieurs, mesdames" indicates he is addressing the other guests/household and any investigators present.  
Topic: Poirot is dramatically accusing and naming the murderer, identifying Mr. Alfred Inglethorp as the culprit (the same man who just attacked him).  
Location/context: Inside the room where the earlier struggle occurred (a chair had been overturned and Poirot had just thrown the assailant to the floor); he is making a public denouement in front of the others present.
fragment:

Poirot is among the company and, after dodging the assailant and causing him to fall, speaks to the gathered men and women ("Messieurs, mesdames") and names Mr. Alfred Inglethorp as the murderer.

Speaker: Hercule Poirot.  
Addressed to: the assembled men and women present at the scene (his audience of guests/household — "Messieurs, mesdames").  
Topic: Poirot is naming and accusing Mr. Alfred Inglethorp as the murderer and, as the chapter title indicates, will proceed to explain how he reached that conclusion.  
Location: in the same room where the scuffle just occurred — before the gathered group in the house.
fragment:
CHAPTER XIII.
POIROT EXPLAINS

annotation:
Speaker: "I" is Captain Arthur Hastings, the narrator and Poirot's friend/assistant.
Addressed to: Hercule Poirot.
Topic: Hastings is protesting—half-angry, half-affectionate—that Poirot deceived him during the investigation and the dramatic unmasking just performed (he feels tricked by Poirot's methods).
Where: Immediately after Poirot's public revelation of the murderer, in front of the assembled company at Roger Ackroyd's house (the room where Poirot has been explaining his case).
fragment:
“Poirot, you old villain,” I said, “I’ve half a mind to strangle you!
What do you mean by deceiving me as you have done?”

annotation:
Speaker: The narrator is Dr James Sheppard (the "I" who spoke the earlier line).  
Addressee: He is speaking to Hercule Poirot, the detective.  
Topic: Dr Sheppard is confronting Poirot about having misled him during the investigation and is demanding an explanation; Poirot is about to explain the case (this is the chapter in which Poirot explains his deductions).  
Location: They are sitting in the library of the country house (Roger Ackroyd's house, Fernly Park). John and Mary are together in the room below; Alfred Inglethorp and Miss Howard have been taken into custody following the recent, hectic days of the investigation.
fragment:
We were sitting in the library. Several hectic days lay behind us. In
the room below, John and Mary were together once more, while Alfred
Inglethorp and Miss Howard were in custody. Now at last, I had Poirot
to myself, and could relieve my still burning curiosity.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot.  
Addressed to: the narrator, Captain Arthur Hastings (who had just accused Poirot of deceiving him).  
Topic: Poirot is about to explain why he misled Hastings and to set out the solution and reasoning behind the recent murder investigation and arrests.  
Where: seated together in the library at Styles (after several hectic days; John and Mary are downstairs reunited, and Alfred Inglethorp and Miss Howard are in custody).
fragment: Poirot did not answer me for a moment, but at last he said:

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot, the Belgian detective.
Addressed to: Captain Arthur Hastings (the narrator), whom Poirot calls "mon ami."
Topic: Poirot is replying to Hastings' accusation that Poirot deceived him during the recent investigation; Poirot denies active deception and says he only allowed Hastings to mislead himself — referring to the investigative ruse and the withholding/revealing of information in the murder case.
Location: They are sitting together in the library of the house, after the case has been largely resolved (other characters are downstairs or in custody).
fragment:
“I did not deceive you, _mon ami_. At most, I permitted you to deceive
yourself.”

annotation:
Speaker: The narrator (Captain Hastings).
Addressee: Hercule Poirot.
Topic: A follow-up question asking why Poirot allowed the narrator to deceive himself — i.e., why Poirot did not tell him the truth sooner or why he acted as he did.
Location: In the library, alone with Poirot (John and Mary are below; two suspects are in custody).
fragment: “Yes, but why?”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot, the Belgian detective.
- Who is addressed: the narrator and Poirot's friend (Captain Hastings).
- Topic: Poirot explains why he did not tell Hastings his suspicions about Mr. Alfred Inglethorp — Hastings's honest, expressive face would have shown his suspicion and so alerted Inglethorp, spoiling their chances of catching him.
- Where they are: not specified in the provided lines (the location is not made clear from the fragment).
fragment:
“Well, it is difficult to explain. You see, my friend, you have a
nature so honest, and a countenance so transparent, that—_enfin_, to
conceal your feelings is impossible! If I had told you my ideas, the
very first time you saw Mr. Alfred Inglethorp that astute gentleman
would have—in your so expressive idiom—‘smelt a rat’! And then,
_bonjour_ to our chances of catching him!”

annotation:
- Speaker: the friend who earlier said “Yes, but why?” — i.e., the person accused of having a too-transparent countenance.
- Addressee: the other companion who used French phrases (“mon ami,” “enfin,” “bonjour”) and explained that he permitted the friend to deceive himself in order to avoid alarming Mr. Alfred Inglethorp.
- Topic: a rebuttal to the claim that the speaker cannot conceal feelings; the speaker asserts they are more diplomatic than given credit for. This refers to the broader plan to keep Alfred Inglethorp unaware and thus “catch” him.
- Where: in the same private conversation between the two men; the precise physical location is not specified in the history.
fragment: “I think that I have more diplomacy than you give me credit for.”

annotation:
- Speaker: Hercule Poirot.
- Addressee: his friend (the person who asked “Yes, but why?” just before — in the books this is Poirot’s companion, Captain Hastings).

- Where: a private conversation during their investigation (spoken informally while they are together on the case, likely in or near the house/room connected with Mr. Alfred Inglethorp).
fragment:
“My friend,” besought Poirot, “I implore you, do not enrage yourself!
Your help has been of the most invaluable. It is but the extremely
beautiful nature that you have, which made me pause.”

Where: They are talking together in private, face-to-face (the exact room isn’t specified in the excerpt).
fragment:
“Well,” I grumbled, a little mollified. “I still think you might have
given me a hint.”

fragment:
“But I did, my friend. Several hints. You would not take them. Think
now, did I ever say to you that I believed John Cavendish guilty? Did I
not, on the contrary, tell you that he would almost certainly be
acquitted?”

fragment:
“_Bon!_ I will reconstruct for you as far as possible. I am inclined to
think that Miss Howard was the master mind in that affair. You remember
her once mentioning that her father was a doctor? Possibly she
dispensed his medicines for him, or she may have taken the idea from
one of the many books lying about when Mademoiselle Cynthia was
studying for her exam. Anyway, she was familiar with the fact that the
addition of a bromide to a mixture containing strychnine would cause
the precipitation of the latter. Probably the idea came to her quite
suddenly. Mrs. Inglethorp had a box of bromide powders, which she
occasionally took at night. What could be easier than quietly to
dissolve one or more of those powders in Mrs. Inglethorp’s large sized
bottle of medicine when it came from Coot’s? The risk is practically
nil. The tragedy will not take place until nearly a fortnight later. If
anyone has seen either of them touching the medicine, they will have
forgotten it by that time. Miss Howard will have engineered her
quarrel, and departed from the house. The lapse of time, and her
absence, will defeat all suspicion. Yes, it was a clever idea! If they
had left it alone, it is possible the crime might never have been
brought home to them. But they were not satisfied. They tried to be too
clever—and that was their undoing.”

- Where: Inside the same room where Cynthia had just kissed them and then “rushed out of the room again” (a sitting/drawing room in the house).
fragment: “What on earth does this mean?” I asked, surprised.

annotation:
Who is speaking: The first-person narrator (the same "me" who was kissed moments earlier).

Who is addressed: No one directly — this is the narrator's internal comment/observation.

What is the topic: The narrator's reaction to Cynthia's cheek‑kiss (she had just kissed the narrator and Poirot); he enjoyed the kiss but felt its publicness made it less pleasurable.

Where are they: In the room they were occupying moments before (Cynthia had just rushed out of the room after kissing them); Poirot and the narrator are present in the house/room where the brief incident occurred.
fragment:
It was very nice to be kissed by Cynthia, but the publicity of the
salute rather impaired the pleasure.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot (the detective).  
Addressee: the narrator ("I" — Captain Hastings) who had just asked the question (and any others present).  
Topic: Poirot explains the meaning of Cynthia's impulsive kiss/exclamation — that Cynthia has realized Monsieur Lawrence does not dislike her as much as she had believed.  
Setting: In the room where Cynthia had just been (she kissed them and then rushed out of the room); Poirot answers from that location, speaking calmly/philosophically.
fragment:
“It means that she has discovered Monsieur Lawrence does not dislike
her as much as she thought,” replied Poirot philosophically.

annotation:
Who is speaking: The narrator ("I" — the story's first-person narrator, likely Captain Hastings) interrupts with "But——".
Who is addressed: Hercule Poirot (who has just explained the situation).
Topic: A reaction to Poirot's explanation that Cynthia has realized Monsieur Lawrence does not dislike her as much as she thought — specifically about the meaning of Cynthia's salute/kiss and its publicity.
Where they are: In the same room/place where the salute/kiss occurred (a public or semi-public setting immediately after the incident).
fragment: “But——”

annotation:
Speaker: one of the people in the group gathered with Poirot (an onlooker — likely Hastings or another guest).  
Addressee: the rest of the group, including Poirot.  
Topic: announcing the arrival/appearance of the man they had been talking about (Monsieur Lawrence / the visitor connected to Cynthia).  
Location: in the room or entrance area of the house where the conversation is taking place — someone has just come into view or entered.  
This line interrupts the conversation about Cynthia and Monsieur Lawrence to point out that the man has arrived.
fragment: “Here he is.”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The first quoted line is spoken by Hercule Poirot. The short "But——" and "Here he is." are from another person present (not named in the fragment).
- Who is addressed: Poirot and the other interlocutor are speaking to one another; they are discussing a woman (referred to as "she") and Monsieur Lawrence.
- Topic: They are commenting that the woman has found out Monsieur Lawrence does not dislike her as much as she had supposed.
- Where they are: They are in a room with a door; at that moment Monsieur Lawrence passes the door and comes into view.
fragment: Lawrence at that moment passed the door.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot (addressing someone in his characteristic French-inflected English: "Monsieur").
Addressee: Mr. Lawrence, the man who has just passed through the door and entered the room.
Topic: Poirot is inviting others to congratulate Lawrence — the fragment does not specify the occasion for the congratulations.
Where: In the room or entry area where a small group is gathered; Lawrence has just come in through the doorway and Poirot calls out to him from the room.
fragment:
“Eh! Monsieur Lawrence,” called Poirot. “We must congratulate you, is
it not so?”

annotation:
Speaker: The passage is the third-person narrator describing characters' reactions. Immediately before, Hercule Poirot spoke ("Eh! Monsieur Lawrence..."), so the spoken line is Poirot addressing Lawrence.

Addressee: Poirot is addressing Lawrence (Monsieur Lawrence). The narrator's lines are not addressed to a character but describe Lawrence's feelings about Cynthia.

Topic: Lawrence's blush and awkward smile because he is in love; Cynthia has just looked (appeared) charming. Poirot's earlier remark ("We must congratulate you") implies the group are congratulating Lawrence on a romantic connection with Cynthia.

Location: At a doorway/entrance of the room/house where Poirot and others (including Cynthia and Lawrence) are gathered — Lawrence has just passed the door. 

Names: "Lawrence" = Monsieur Lawrence; "Cynthia" = the woman he loves; "Poirot" = Hercule Poirot, who spoke the congratulatory remark.
fragment:
Lawrence blushed, and then smiled awkwardly. A man in love is a sorry
spectacle. Now Cynthia had looked charming.

annotation:
Speaker: "I" is the story's first-person narrator (the usual Hastings-like narrator). 
Addressee: The sigh is not directed to anyone—it's an internal or small audible reaction.
Topic: A reaction to the scene just described—Poirot's cheerfully urging congratulations to Lawrence, Lawrence's embarrassed blush (he is in love), and Cynthia looking charming.
Location: In the same room/near the doorway where Lawrence has just passed (they are gathered in the house, by the door/entrance).
fragment: I sighed.

annotation:
Speaker: Hercule Poirot.  
Addressed to: the first-person narrator ("I" in the history), likely Captain Hastings.  
Topic: Poirot is asking why the narrator sighed — reacting to the scene (Poirot's congratulating Mr. Lawrence and Cynthia's charm / Lawrence's embarrassment).  
Where: the same room/gathering where Lawrence and Cynthia are present; the three are standing nearby one another.
fragment: “What is it, _mon ami?_”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: "I" — the story's narrator (the same person who sighed in the previous line).
- Who is addressed: the person who just asked "What is it, mon ami?" — a friend present in the scene (one of the other characters already mentioned).
- What is the topic: the narrator, feeling sad, replies that nothing is wrong and offers a compliment: the two women present are "delightful" (praising Cynthia and the other woman present).
- Where they are: in the same immediate scene with Lawrence and Cynthia (a social setting; they are in each other's company in the room).
fragment: “Nothing,” I said sadly. “They are two delightful women!”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Hercule Poirot (he finishes the sentence).
- Who is addressed: The narrator (Captain Hastings), who sighed and spoke in the previous lines.
- Topic: Hastings' romantic disappointment — he admires "two delightful women" but neither is available to him; Poirot consoles him and suggests they might "hunt together" (i.e., work on another case) as a way to cheer him up.
- Where they are: Not specified in the fragment or preceding lines; simply the two are conversing together (in private/the same room).
fragment:
“And neither of them is for you?” finished Poirot. “Never mind. Console
yourself, my friend. We may hunt together again, who knows? And then——”

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The lines are spoken by Hercule Poirot (the detective) and the narrator ("I", almost certainly Captain Arthur Hastings).  
- Who is addressed: Poirot addresses the narrator as "mon ami" (French for "my friend"); the narrator is replying to Poirot.  
- What is the topic: The narrator is expressing sadness that "they are two delightful women" neither of whom is a romantic match for him; Poirot teases and consoles him, suggesting they may hunt (investigate) together again.  
- Where they are: The fragment is the story's close; the exact physical location is not specified in the fragment—it is a private, concluding conversation between Poirot and the narrator.  
- Note: "THE END" simply marks the end of the story.
